	<review>
		<date>2002-07-15</date>
		<username>Empress (jupiturgrl@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>"Moulin Rouge!": "Obnoxious Drivel Devoid of Any Dignity Whatsoever" or "A Lovely Romantic Story"?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I must say that I had extreme misgivings (mostly deserved) for "Moulin Rouge!" And though I quite liked Baz Luhrmann's "Romeo+Juliet," "Moulin Rouge!" wasn't the least bit appetizing for me. Well, that isn't entirely true; I very much wanted to see the lavish costumes, spectacular sets, and lush colors. And after seeing a clip of Nicole Kidman singing in a Tv interview (and liking what I heard), I wanted to hear more.This movie abruptly morphs from an in emotionally-insipid, methamphetamine-pumped, seizure-inducing, one-dimensional cinematic failure of epic proportions into a tolerable, almost-touches-your-heart love story. The flow of the story itself and the personalities of the characters do such a quick unbelievable 180 that I'm left with no choice but to review each half of the movie separately.~First HalfGiven all the energetic promos, one would think "Moulin Rouge!" starts with an offensive explosion of mind-blowing pomp and outrageous fanfare of debauchery. On the contrary, it starts off pretty interesting with a little man singing mournfully in a gloomy town greyed with melancholy. In a dingy closeted hotel room, the grieving writer Christian (Ewan McGregor) drags his heavily pain-ridden heart to his typewriter to tell his story, their story--a story of a man and a woman who fell in love only to lose out to Fate and its cruelty. This is a completely unexpected mood for the beginning of this story. It made me think, "Oh....Maybe this won't be as bad as I thought.."But, have no fear, movie-goers, the "offensive explosion of mind-blowing pomp and outrageous fanfare of debauchery" DOES happen--only a few minutes later than expected, and a whole lot more offensive and sickening. And when I say "sickening," I do mean literally. The too-ugly characters (due to overdone make-up) and their too-quick movements and their too-fast speech, and the too-quick camera cuts all made me want to throw up.The year is 1899. Why do you watch a movie set in 1899? To experience another era, to get lost in the wondrousness of that time: its song, its dance, its dress, its society? To even romanticize it? No, no, no! The movie doesn't allow you to do this. Why? Because you have a bunch of tawdry people screaming and singing songs that you know don't belong in this time, leaving some center inside of you fighting what you're hearing and seeing as if it were blasphemous. That's why.Now, one may say that maybe the director *wants* you to be offended by what goes on in the Moulin Rouge. But it isn't so much what happens there that offends you--as all you're seeing is singing and dancing--but the camera cuts and the too-fast speech are what's offensive. It's too fast to follow (and you're talking to a woman who surfs the internet, watches "Braveheart," does math homework, and listens to the radio--all at the same time! She sings along to the radio, she reads her little newsgroups, and she can look at the Tv to see as well as hear her favorite "Braveheart" scenes at the proper times since she can devote part of her brain to following the storyline. And, yes, sometimes she even likes a little taste of Rob Zombie's "Living Dead Girl" and "Dragula"). As I was saying, it's so visually offensive you can't even appreciate the costumes, the singing, and the choreography. It's like getting a spa treatment and at the same time being forcefed liquified earwax and toothpaste soup from a toilet. Extremely unpleasant. Extremely frustrating.Why didn't I just turn it off? One, I wanted to finish watching this movie so I could rip it apart here. And two, I still wanted to hear Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor sing "Come What May."Actually, it isn't so much visually-offensive as it is scary. When thinking of the jerky camera movements, I suspect this movie was directed by a bunch of mental patients overdosing on speed.Even before seeing all the action in the Moulin Rouge, you're subjected to the same jerky camera cuts and rapid speech in Christian's hotel room where he joins with Bohemian revolutionaries (John Leguizamo among them). There is a lot of dialogue, but sadly you can only snatch a word here and there. You don't get what's being said or who's saying it. Obviously, it makes it extremely difficult--if not impossible--to understand what's happening. This scene ends with a cameo by a green fairydust-sprinkling singing Kylie Minogue Tinkerbell that leaves you thinking, "What the heck was that?" and wondering what Christian and his new Boho friends were smoking.Speeding ahead, they have the guy-sees-girl-across-a-crowded-room-and-it's-love-at-first-sight scene. When courtesan Satine (Nicole Kidman) and Christian finally are alone together, she thinks he's the regular "visitor" and puts on her sex kitten act, leaving him completely flustered but wanting to break through to the real Satine. She finally catches on that he isn't her regular John. "Big Bad Guy" Duke of Monroth (Richard Roxburgh) has been promised a romp in the hay with Satine and interrupts Christian and Satine. While Christian hides and tries to sneak out, Satine distracts the Duke. Her gift of "[making men] believe what they want to believe" backfires when the Duke falls in love with her and believes she loves him in return. As the Duke's finances are crucial to the Moulin Rouge and Satine's career, it puts Satine in an obvious predicament.Unfortunately, not a bit of what I was able to understand of the plot makes the least bit of difference. The dialogue was hard to catch and the characters were all so one-dimensional. It's as though the overblown pomp and special effects left the director no time for attention to dramatic details such as lingering closeups and time for the viewers to believe in the lovers' love for each other. What's worse is that Kidman and McGregor have no chemistry. It's not for lack of trying; They just don't have it. It often seems that they act within their own little "boxes," acting *at* each other as opposed to *with* each other. Basically, you're left with nothing substantial for your heart to soak in. It's quite sad as the second half of the movie suddenly slows down enough to draw you into the lovers' world..~Second HalfThis part of the movie is somewhat enjoyable since it's a bit more coherent than its first half. You're often in a slow mode of suspense, wondering exactly how this story will turn out.The one downside, however, is that the style of the movie and some characters do a complete 180. There is more dialogue *not* at warp speed and less overblown production numbers, leaving more room for story and true character interaction. Also, Harold Zidler (Jim Broadbent) changes from a greedy, seedy, one-dimensional, immoral PimpDaddy to a starting-to-care nearly Father-like sorta-sympathetic figure. Suddenly, he has another side to him. But this totally doesn't wash with the first half of the movie. There is no transition that I can see.~What Did I Like?Kidman was good, as was McGregor. But neither of them deserve nominations. Leguizamo was excellent as he is in all he does. Richard Roxburgh was quite effective; He made me hate his character so much it will take me a great deal to separate him from "The Duke's" disagreeable image should he be in a different role in the future.~What Did I Love?The costumes were better than excellent, particularly Satine's outfits. They didn't look the least bit cheap or cheesy. My favorite was Satine's oriental-style gown, the one with the wine-colored empire-waisted bottom and gold-embroidered black kimono-style top, topped off with a bejeweled golden fanned-halo headpiece fit for an Empress. It is the most beautiful costume I've ever seen, and it made me feel dumpy in my super-baggy Pepto-pink sweater and sweatpants.The look of the movie was quite good. The sets were gorgeous, particularly Satine's luxurious red-toned room which resembled a jewelry box. The computer-generated city was realistic in a fantasy sort of way. Unfortunately, they didn't give us time to really look at them, giving the viewer a feeling of sprinting through an art gallery.The characters themselves were done up quite well. McGregor was sexy. Kidman was trussed up as beautifully as an art piece--Not too difficult as the combination of flawless skin, long wavy red hair, and defined blue eyes is classic.The lighting was genius. Whatever was done brought out every red and blue color and displayed it to its fullest and deepest.I love "Come What May." Kidman's and McGregor's voices mesh well for this song.~What Would Have Made It All Better?Number One? Chemistry. Kidman and McGregor didn't even convince me that they were friends. They were actors playing a part and they seemed like actors playing a part. Why the director didn't notice this right away and point it out and at least attempt to create some chemistry is beyond me.Number Two? Original songs. The constant barrage of well-known relatively-modern hits left me disoriented, though I actually like these songs well enough. Everytime a lyric was uttered, my mind would instantly call up the original singer and start comparing every inflection to the original version, distracting me from the storyline and ultimately destroying the illusion that I was in 1899 to witness this love story. The effect is about as unpleasant as being doused with cold water during a dream-filled sleep.Number Three? Dialogue. DO NOT use, I repeat, DO NOT use lyrics from those well-known hits in regular speech between characters. Why? One, it still creates the aforementioned effect. Two, from a man's mouth, it comes off as a really bad "pick-up line." Three, a bunch of balding old men dressed as bankers singing and bopping around to Nirvana's hard-rockin' 'n' head-bashin' "Smells Like Teen Spirit" makes Carlton Banks of "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" look like Fred Astaire. This can only evince pity in the viewer.Number Four? Speed. I know you love the fast cuts, Baz, but this was just too much. I seriously wonder if he should avoid lawsuits and slap a warning label on it, informing the viewer that this movie could induce seizures. Seriously.~Why Is "Romeo+Juliet" So Much Better?One, a good number of those songs, though modern, weren't well-known to me; They were also background music and didn't wind up as lines of conversation. Two, Leonardo DiCaprio and Claire Danes had warmth and chemistry, not to mention shining true talent (at least back then for DiCaprio). Three, the cuts weren't quick and numerous enough to steal focus from the story of the lovers. Four, and most importantly, the dialogue was still Shakespeare, thus allowing "Romeo+Juliet" and its actors to retain their DIGNITY.~ConclusionI will not reveal what happens at the end of the movie, as that would spoil it. My recommendation is to watch the movie from start to finish so you can see for yourself. If the second half of the movie agrees with you, in future viewings you may want to fastforward about an hour, or at the very least look away from the quick-cut sequences since it's about as harmful to your mind as a solar eclipse is to your eyes. And don't forget the Tylenol for the inevitable headache you'll get as you try to take in the dialogue.On a "report card" scale.. First half: D- Last half: C+ Could have been a: B+</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-06-20</date>
		<username>hippiegal</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Movie you will adore or hate</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have very mixed feelings about this movie. The elements that work, they work wonderfully. The aspects that don't work, well, oh brother.Things that work-Nicole Kidman-she steals the show with her classic beauty, charm, charisma and sheer star power. She was perfect casting.-The sets- The sets were beautiful. You can tell a lot of work was put in these stunning sets. They're wonderful eye candy._The costumes- I wanted to design costumes for plays when I was young.So I was impressed with the outfits. Heck if I was twenty pounds thinner I would use similar dresses for Halloween._Ewan Mcgregor -Even though through the whole movie all he does is act lovesick and pout. For people who only know him as Obi-Wan it shows his wide range of talent. Bad things about the movie_The music-There's just something wrong about using Nirvana and madonna songs for 19th century France. It's just tacky. It's almost as if Baz Luhrman thinks that modern audiences won't tolerate showtunes so top 40 hits must be used. I understand his logic on using modern music, but it almost insulting for musical lovers.-The love story- I watched this after having a massive fight with my finance so maybe I was too cynical. But it's so phony and Disney-esque. But how could anybody not be cynical about falling in love in three seconds over a Elton John song? -the shrieking- how come all through out the first half on the movie every character was to shriek and yell their lines? I found it very annoying.On a another note Is it just me or does Nicole Kidman seems to beautiful and active for someone who is dying? Also doesn't the Duke look amazingly like David Spade?Over all a very mixed bag. I'm a musical fan and I wasn't sure what to make of it. From reading the reviews people adore or just don't get it. I'm in the middle.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-06-19</date>
		<username>capkronos (capkronos00@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Gorgeous, colorful, stylish,...BRAINLESS!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let's face it, a huge chunk of money was sunk into MOULIN ROUGE! and when you're working with a big budget you can make visual miracles a reality. It's the same thing Lucas did with STAR WARS, EPISODE 1, another dazzling display of visual technique. That said, this film, like EPISODE 1, is completely empty and worthless beyond the asthetics, and it's bludgened to death by overlength and cornball dramatics. I just don't get the appeal of these things. I'd also like to note that escapist cinema is a good thing, but it does NOT have to insult our intelligence. I think I had a difficult time swallowing this because of the ineffectual, cliche-ridden and cheesy dialogue &amp; plot developments, but apparently that didn't matter to many people since this landed smack in the middle of the Top 250 list and got nominated for so many awards.Ewan McGregor is becoming a sell-out (just look what big bucks did to once-good actors Jeff Goldblum and Nicolas Cage) and Nicole Kidman is asked to do very little than stand around a look ravishing (she's very good at that, but why couldn't Madonna have played this role?). Baz Luhrmann's intentions here are to get across that (I'm quoting him from the 2002 Oscar telecast) "Love is the big picture!" I respond with a big fat "No sh*t there, Baz!" OK, so the execution of the worn out plot is different, but if hyperkinetic camerawork, spastic characters bouncing off the walls and overkill special FX is the price I have to pay for originality, then I'll pass.Little rings true in this film. The emotions are forced and fake. The reinterpretations of classic songs are terrible, the singing voices are pretty mediocre...Catherine Martin and others did brilliant work with the art direction and costumes and she was rightfully applauded, so I will give the film that much. A far as this new age of musicals, Lars von Trier's DANCER IN THE DARK is leagues better than this attention-hogging "musical for a new millenium." Bjork delivered a haunting performance in DANCER that easily eclipses Kidman's work here (and I don't mean to state the obvious by adding she's a much better singer). Unfortunately for the Icelandic elfen princess, she's not as easy on the eyes as Kidman...and that seems to be what's most important to movie-goers and critics.I recommend DANCER over this any day, but I always applaud originality, even when it doesn't actually work as is the case with MOULIN ROUGE!, so...Score: 4 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Flawed beauty</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was REALLY looking forward to this. The opening credits only heightened the anticipation and for the first twenty minutes or so it was a magnificent spectacle, but then the film got bogged down in repetitive padding. The musical numbers seemed ten times as long as they needed to be and I started to get both bored and irritated, a mood which carried on to the end credits - a shame, as performances were great and the whole film looked absolutely stunning. But I would rather have had more of a script which did justice to the film rather than the same bloody Elton John song seemingly over and over again. I shall rent it out at a later date, just to enjoy the beauty all over again, but I'll be fast forwarding over a lot of the musical bits......</fullReview>

		<date>2002-05-16</date>
		<username>phiggins</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The potency of cheap music</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoilers. As usual. Was it George Orwell who talked about the potency of cheap music? Or Dennis Potter? No, he was the one who described the songs with which he bolstered his work as "vomit". Nice man. Whoever it was, cheap music has never been more potent than in "Moulin Rouge", a swirling, dizzying, annoying, wonderful mess of a movie, in which songs that any right-thinking individual would happily run a million miles to avoid are turned into spine-tingling little wonders of emotion and power. How is this done? Simply by getting two of the 21st Century's most attractive stars - McGregor and Kidman - to sing them. I never would have believed it possible for me to enjoy a version of Elton John's "Your Song" so much. In fact, it's almost embarrassing how enjoyable this film is. Sure, there are mistakes - the "Like a Virgin" debacle, the desperately unfunny antics of Ewan's sidekicks, who have very little to do except be irritating - but the end result is truly a work of pop culture greatness. Kidman and McGregor are largely responsible for why this movie works so well. They glow, they shine, they sparkle, they radiate, they have an amazing on-screen chemistry, they sing (They SING!), they are Stars. Watching them is the most awesome pleasure I've had in a cinema since "Breakdance II - Electric Boogaloo". And I'm not just saying that. "Moulin Rouge" is not perfect - critics who accuse it of self-indulgence and inanity are not exactly wrong, but they miss the point: it's a film about surface and image and glamour and silly lovesongs and the deep and profound pleasure those trivial things can provide. Thanks for reading.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-05-09</date>
		<username>lwjoslin</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>We'll always have the Green Fairy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Obviously, this movie has its audience, though I'm not among them. I had to watch the DVD in increments, since it made me restless and impatient. "Moulin Rouge" is well cast and handsomely produced, but its thinly-plotted tale of star-crossed lovers serves only as a framework on which to hang an endless succession of musical numbers, many of which simply don't work, or go on too long, or both. Set in 1900 Paris, the movie makes use of pop songs and show tunes that are well out of period, ranging from "Lady Marmalade" to "Roxanne" to "Like a Virgin" (the occasion for an embarrassingly forced and awkward dance number) to "Your Song," to name just a very few. I've liked "Your Song" for 30 years, but if one more character, one more time, had said, "It's a little bit funny, this feeling inside," I'd have hit the STOP button once and for all. One moment, and one moment only, in "Moulin Rouge" works the intended magic on me: the Green Fairy, a wicked Tinkerbell, springs to hallucinatory life from the label on a bottle of absinthe, trailing a shower of green sparks. The scene (which comes in the movie's first ten minutes, more's the pity) is less than a minute long, but manages to feature overlapping musical quotes from "The Hills are Alive," "Children of the Revolution," and the theme song from the movie "The Boy with Green Hair" (the song about the "very strange enchanted boy"). I watched that scene about 50 times before finally returning the DVD to the video store. More of her fairy dust and this movie might have worked better. All told, though, "Moulin Rouge" is frustrating, irritating, and hyperactive. As the French say, chacun a son gout.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-28</date>
		<username>Jeremy Bristol</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A Spectacular Spectacular without Spectacular Characters (Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Baz Luhrmann has been quoted (or was it one of the producers?) as saying he was trying to make a musical for the future. Well, how can one make even a modern musical when the heroine is dying of consumption (i.e. tuberculosis, same as Rizzo in Midnight Cowboy). I can just see Susan Sontag bringing out a new edition of her essay-book "Illness as Metaphor" just to combat this movie's totally old-fashioned depiction of a woman dying beautifully from consumption (doesn't she *just* glow when she coughs up blood?). Countless stories over the years (at least according to Sontag) have ended with these romanticised, tragic literary deaths (more recently, these deaths are from AIDS or cancer).Another thing that makes Moulin Rouge! old-fashioned is the fact that the music is (almost?) entirely pre-existing, most from the Eighties (two whole songs by Madonna) and some even older ("Sound of Music" and "My Song," both of which were apparently written by Christian, not Rodgers and Hammerstein and Barry Taupin and Elton John). In fact, in many ways, the movie seems to be a relic of the Eighties--like Ferris Bueller, the villain is a loud obnoxious clown of a person, while the heroes are young and more "honest" (supposedly exemplified by the midget/sitar that "can tell no lies"). In the end, the movie is just a rehash-on-speed of Titanic, all the way down to the frame that indicates who lives and who dies at the very beginning.6 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

Words cannot express my pain for the film makers. As a fan of musicals, this was nothing to take notice of. 		<date>2002-04-26</date>
		<username>kirby579</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>At Least it was Pretty</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I really did enjoy watching this film, but i would be hesitant to reccomend it to an unsuspecting audience. The plot was incredibely banal, a golden hearted hooker meets lovelorn poet story. Which will triumph in the end "True Love" or "Love of Money"? The suspense might actually get to you, if weren't for the exceedingly effected acting style of the two main characters. Not to say that all the acting is awful, John Leguizamo and Jim Broadbent were fantastic in their supporting roles, as were most of the other minor characters. Once i stopped paying attention to the plot and the lovers, however, i really enjoyed the film. In addition to Baz Luhrman's eclectic genius, Something must be said for the absolute neon brilliance of Catherine Martin, the production designer (who also did such a fantastic job with Baz's other films, Romeo+Juliet and Strictly Ballroom)as well as the cinematographer Donald McAlpine. The world they created was absolutely beautiful to watch. Everything visually was stunning to the utmost degree. However, while the gaudy decadence of the set and frantic editing pace appealed to me, it may overwhelm some audience members. As a rule of thumb, if you don't like fast paced jumpy editing sequences (think MTV or Baz's other big hit Romeo+Juliet), you proboly won't enjoy the visual effects of this film. As a musical i couldn't decide if this made the cut. Certainely the opening brothel number was fast-paced and exciting, but the majority of the rest of the songs were all sappy love song clips which i thought fell a bit flat. I just didn't feel the excitment of that opening song was ever recaptured throughout the rest of the film.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-04-22</date>
		<username>herzograven</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>McGregor saves the day!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Prior to watching Moulin Rouge! , I only heard amazing things about this movie. However I was warned that it IS a musical, and I was not sure how well this movie was really made since I am not a fan of musicals. As the movie begins Ewan McGregor's narration lays an impression on the viewer. The opening scene is serious and sad when McGregor is explaining what has happened. His narration continues the movie changes rapidly into a ridiculous comedy that does not seem appealing at all. It continues for another hour to have this great touch of a ridiculous comedy which is not funny I might add. The first hour of the movie was completely boring and seemed very weak, however in certain scenes McGregor proved his acting ability very well and showed the audience how well he is capable to act. The story does not pick up until half way through the movie. That is when the climax begins and the story begins to take a serious shape compared to the first half. The second hour of the movie has many twists and turns in the sense of the complications between the two main characters. They are caught between their love and their duties and seem to forget how badly they are tangled up in this obstacle. Again the story changes rapidly from a ridiculous comedy into a serious romantic drama. It continues with its more serious side until it hits the end. The ending was not unexpected but without a doubt it can be said that it was a better ending than most recent movies that have been released. For a regular movie person the ending would be predictable, but the overall performance near the end raises and became much better than it was at the beginning of the movie. One has to sit through the movie in order to completely understand what is going on and in order to determine what kind of movie this is. To come to a conclusion and give this movie a definite genre, Moulin Rouge! is a musical love story beyond any doubts, it is preformed in a comedic style as the movie opens, however it changes into a dramatic love story as it proceeds. As a personal note I might add that this movie was no Oscar material accept Ewan McGregor's performance. I believe that with this movie or even his prior movies he has proven that he is a great actor with great abilities. Him being in the cast was probably the only reason that I did watch this movie. As another private note I wish to add that for the 2001 Oscar nominations if there was anyone worthy of winning the `Beat Actor of the Year' award it would have been McGregor rather than Denzel Washington for `Training Day'. This once again proves that the Oscars are not concerned with ART in movies but rather larger box office digits. One last statement that I want to close this off with; this movie is not for everyone, you have to sit through a lot of senseless material in order to get through this and it will not be easy (I warn you now!). As I mentioned it before, if this movie has one strong element to it then it was Ewan McGregor, In other words, McGregor saves this movie from being `very bad' to `okay'.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>I'm not sure</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What to think of it ? Moulin Rouge mixes times and cultures with no respect of anything, and it's fun. Seeing the mythic Zidler, Moulin Rouge's owner, singing Madonna's "like a virgin" song to fool a jealous duke, yes, it's fun. Some visual effects are brilliant, really, and Kylie Minogue, in her twenty seconds cameo as a "absynth spirit" is great too. The whole decoration is great too. Now the bad thing : the storyline is simple, but at no moment I wanted to believe in it, I never felt concerned with the love story, Nicole Kidman plays like a fish : wet big eyes but a few expressivity (maybe not her fault : the role is not very well written). The camera does too much slow motions, it makes go sea sick. Sometimes, the camera can't stay showing a still thing more than one second and that is not very enjoyable too. I'm sure this mvie could have been much much better with a real director : Luhrmann has strong visions, good ideas (too much ideas maybe), but he is not a great director for me, I felt exactly the same with Romeo+Juliette. This movie can go in the same box as "le pacte des loups" (brotherhood of the wolves) : funny, better than a waste but far from the masterpiece some calls it.</fullReview>

Was it the costumes? Was it the fact that a Jedi Knight was singing? The answer is YES!!!!!!!I took Drama class for six years in school, and I'm telling you right now, I would've loved to do a musical like this in school. Instead we did "Mame"! If you want "Lady Marmalade", get soundtrack #1. If you want anything else, soundtrack 2 is for you.Anyway, Moulin Rouge is a lot of fun, but I'll tell you it's extremely bizarre! 		<date>2002-04-04</date>
		<username>FilmNutgm</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>My feelings about Moulin Rouge! are as schizophrenic as the film itself!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**POSSIBLE SPOILERS** throughout. I saw this film last year after it reached the second-run movie theater market. Had I paid $7-10 to see it instead of $1, I might be more harsh about what I felt were the movie's shortcomings. As it was, after being absolutely flummoxed by the beginning--(and wondering if I should cut my losses and leave), I stayed to the end and found that I could enjoy many moments of the film. My problem is that after reading many of the reviews on this website--and quite a few on other websites--I find that I can agree with pretty much everything anyone says--(EXCEPT the criticism of Ewan MacGregor's singing. I thought it was marvellous and saved many of the musical numbers.) As for the movie: It was too frenetic. The love story did need time to breathe to have emotional resonance. I too had trouble deciphering whether the director was satirizing romantic musicals or paying tribute to them. That said, I also can agree with those who found it moving and dazzling and fascinating. My feelings about the film fluctuate as much as the camera work. I love opera so you know I can suspend a lot of disbelief, but even I need some emotional sincerity to hang my hat on. The scenes where Satine and Christian are falling in love had that; as did the scenes of the friendship among the "Children of the Revolution" and their creative struggles. The death at the end did not because I did not feel that Nicole Kidman, who did a good job with a"woman as symbol" role, and Ewan Macgregor, who was charming and credible in a role written as more of a type than a flesh and blood person were not allowed uninterrupted, non-gimmicked up screen time to give their scenes emotional richness and space. I think this is one film where I'll always cherish certain scenes from the film, but never end up whole-heartedly loving the entire picture. If the director had toned down his delight with various bags of tricks and avoided the temptation to try have his romance/satire/parody cake and eat it too, this film could have been a classic. Love that ends in heartbreak and death can rarely co-exist with looniness and glitter. I wish more filmakers would remember that. There's nothing wrong with ungilded sentiment. That said, when I see the film again, I'll probably have yet another set of opinions about it. I guess I should just be glad that anyone dares to make a film that isn't so bland that everyone can agree on it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-03-27</date>
		<username>DizzyDitz</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Did I miss something?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't usually comment on movies just to trash them, but the popularity of Moulin Rouge has always baffled me. Besides the later arrivals, the movie seasons of 2000-2002 had been dismal(Jennifer Lopez was up for an Oscar for "The Cell", Julia Roberts actually won an Oscar). I went to see Moulin Rouge because it looked interesting and I liked the actors involved, and, frankly, because there was nothing else to see. Moulin Rouge is a melodramatic, sometimes funny musical. The storyline is sappy, sagging, and cheesy; reminiscent of Gothic literature. Nicole Kidman does a fine job as Satine, but even her genuine emotion can't save this musical from seeming corny. The music is decent, but not heart-wrenching. There are a few appropriate songs (Elton John's "How Wonderful Life Is" is used endearingly), but the most memorable moments come from the comic numbers (See "Like a Virgin"), and the unintentionally comic numbers (See "Roxeanne".) A standout is Jim Broadbent, who is absolutely fantastic as the Moulin Rouge's manager, approaching the performance level set by Joel Grey in "Cabaret". Don't expect a heartbreakingly poignant movie, but if singing star-cross'd lovers guided by fate and fortune are your specialty, you'll be pleased. For everyone else, you can expect to be sufficiently entertained.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-03-25</date>
		<username>PhilauraJ</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I Enjoyed Mariah Carey's Glitter more</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For my taste "Glitter" was a more satisfying musical. This film seemed very cold which did not sit well with me for watching a love story. Though I was very impressed with the fact that Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor could sing as well as they did, and listening to familiar old love songs incorporated into a new muscial was novel and fun, I could not warm up to the cartoon-like 2 dimensional characters. I found myself visually stimulated by the color and excitement enough to hold my attention to the end, but had no sentiment for the characters nor sympathy for their plight; and nothing really memorable that stuck with me afterwards. It was worth seeing, but the quality of musical talent, the overall attractiveness of the romantic leads both physically and emotionally were more satisfying in the love story "Glitter". Not by any means a flawless film either, but more satisfying in my book.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-03-23</date>
		<username>Walter Frith</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Too much editing!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor are fabulous in this movie and it is well directed. The writing is standard for a musical: nothing great and passable but the choreography is expertly timed and the sets and costumes are lavish. But there is too much editing. Director Baz Luhrmann cuts his film too rapidly. Sure, rhythm is important to a film but his film is cut like an action piece and not a musical. Legendary dancer Fred Astaire would ask his directors to use the editing as little as possible during his dance numbers and the audience absorbed them perfectly. 'Moulin Rouge' is a return to the musical, a genre in movies that never impressed me much because I always felt that they needed to be seen live and that film just contained them too much and put them into a fish bowl.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-23</date>
		<username>MoonsofJupiter</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>It was 50-50</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this movie just in time for Oscar night. After all the hype I was expecting something a little better than this mixed bag. The execution was highly original; unfortunately, all that originality was wasted on the most overdone plot ever invented. Ewan MacGregor was perfect in his role, plus we don't get to see many handsome actors these days. Jim Broadbent as the scary old theater owner was excellent. What falls down is Nicole Kidman's performance. She's slim and exotic, etc. but she's not a strong actress and I feel she relies more on big eyes and good lighting to portray her character. In one excrutiating scene she does a very bad Meg Ryan impression that turned me off her character for the rest of the movie. Another weak point is the duke, who is portrayed comically as a sadsack cuckold, constantly having the wool pulled over his eyes as the two lovers go at it under his nose, but yet the whole plot hinges on the others' fear of him. It doesn't work. The story was a good half hour too long. There's Satine trembling and sobbing yet again...we get it. She's sad. The good parts of the movie: the supporting cast, the quick pacing, the high energy of the song and dance numbers, and the juxtaposition of different scenes during the Roxanne emote-fest.  I don't advise against this movie, but I don't strongly recommend it. But if it leads to Ewan MacGregor getting more leading man roles in musicals or romances, then it's done its job.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-03-14</date>
		<username>(Mimi Marquez)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Ummmmm....no</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I agree with others who referred to this movie as a "wasted opportunity." The cinematography was beautiful and the idea original, but it was WAY too long and WAY too flawed to keep my interest.The concept is unique; I enjoyed how some of the contemporary songs came to life as lines in the movie, but thought the concept was horribly overdone. I could smell "Like a Virgin" a mile away, and would've turned the movie off altogether if I hadn't invested so much time already. They obviously had talented writers working for this movie. Why not create more original, appropriate, unobnoxious pieces instead? The budget was so lavish and the costumes so beautiful....I just felt like the writing fell short.I also feel that the love story was extremely overrated. I had heard this was one of the best love stories of all time....the kind of love that everyone looks for. Without giving the story away, I just can't agree with this whatsoever. The two lovers barely know each other. Their relationship is totally superficial, and is plagued with self-superiority, jealousy, and misunderstanding. I got the impression that if the drama was put aside, this couple would last about two weeks. It brought me back to high school all over again.But perhaps the biggest flaw, in my opinion, was Ewan McGregor's singing. Dear God, I teach elementary music and my first graders sing better then he does. My knowledge of vocal music is fairly limited...I am by no means a singing snob... but it was extremely obvious that the poor guy has never had a voice lesson in his life. The low notes were fine...but as soon as he started reaching for those high ones every note was SO piercing and so awful. He didn't do anything with them....just belted them out at the top of his lungs and held them there for excruciating periods of time. It was honestly some of the worst on-key singing I have ever heard in my life.There were a few times that I really enjoyed the way the movie seemed to be going. I was never very actively involved in the "love story," but John Leguizamo is hilarious and there were some dramatic climaxes that had my attention. Unfortunately, these all ended in disappointing ways.Ultimately, I enjoyed the fresh concept, brilliant colors, and eccentric use of songs in this movie. Other then that, I was thoroughly disappointed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A MTV type musical</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Baz Luhrmann's "Moulin Rouge!" explodes onto the screen. The camera starts off moving around never truly settling down on one particular person. The musical sequences (and there are many) play right to the MTV music video generation including many popular songs from the last 20 years sung by the characters. The editing, though, jars the viewer to the point of eye soreness. The story revolves around a writer (Ewan McGregor) and a performer (Nicole Kidman) who fall in love despite a few obstacles. The acting is very good, but this musical just feels a little too stylish and never lets you fully into its fantasy world. A 5 out of 10.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-02-23</date>
		<username>Rod-88</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Creative Misfire</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What a weird movie. It's like `The Wizard of OZ' on drugs. Baz Luhrmann, co-writer and director, and Craig Pearce, co-writer, have created an utterly, decadent fantasy that pushes the envelope of the imagination. This movie is a testament that there are no boundaries when making a movie these days. The computer-generated images of the Moulin Rouge and Paris in 1900 are fascinating. The camera shots that seem to have no seams, zoom through the city, and come to a close-up of an actor are great. However, I can't say I enjoyed `Moulin Rouge' that much. It just seemed way too busy, and it could have been better without all of the silliness. The love story that is central in the plot, was, in fact, interesting and touching, but unfortunately there are too many campy distractions. While watching `Moulin Rouge', it reminded me of a couple of movies. The first that I thought of was 1996's `Romeo + Juliet'. I later found out found that he co-wrote and directed it as well. The second I thought of was the Beatles' `Help' because of the playfulness and zaniness of some of the scenes. So if you liked the style of `Romeo + Juliet', you may enjoy `Moulin Rouge'. The music and songs were good and bad at times. Luhrmann and Pearce take famous songs and blend them to create some interesting medleys. Many artists are sampled, from Nirvana to Dolly Parton. Madonna, the Beatles, and Elton John also have large chunks of songs thrown in. The combinations are not always great but are original. My favorite scene in the movie is when Christian (Ewan McGregor) is trying to convince Satine (Nicole Kidman) that they should be lovers. Christian and Satine sing lyrics from famous love songs, while they are in on top of her elephant-shaped apartment (yes, she lives in an elephant). They end up singing David Bowie's "Heroes" (great song).McGregor is outstanding, as the aptly named, Christian; the poet who falls in love with the most sought after prostitute at the Moulin Rouge. His singing voice is good, and he handled his dramatic scenes very well. Kidman is Satine; the hooker that falls for the poet and suddenly develops morals (the hooker with the heart of gold). I have never liked Kidman, and I have a hard time believing that Satine was the most popular prostitute. I don't see it. She does sing well, however. If you are a fan, you should like this new dimension of her.The best performance in the film was by Jim Broadbent, as Harold Zidler, the owner and ?pimp' of the Moulin Rouge. He was great. He reminded me of the wizard in the "Wizard of OZ". He was funny and he sang well. The bottom line is that I am glad I saw this movie, however the craziness and silliness was taken too far for my tastes. I wish Luhrmann had made a more serious movie that was consistent with the love story. I can, however, appreciate the creativity and work that went into this movie; it is quite an accomplishment. I think if you are a fan of Broadway musicals, you should like it. 6 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-02-23</date>
		<username>julie keilty</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The re-birth of the musical</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I would have to say that the first twenty minutes of this film are the most crucial. It's during this period that you are either going to love or loathe this film. For me, it was one of the greatest cinematic experiences I've ever had.Never before have I seen a film which makes such a brilliant and imaginative use of colour. This film, along with Baz Luhrmann's other two films(Strictly Ballroom and Romeo and Juliet)practically eat colour.This film has everything. It has comedy, drama, thrills and tragedy. But it is the music that makes this picture truly special. There is one particular scene which deserves special praise and that has to be the rendition of Madonna's Like a Virgin,which is both amusing and funny.This film fully deserves its Oscar nominations. But one thing is bugging me. Why has Baz Luhrmann been criminally ignored from the best director nominations? Here is a man who has probably re-invented the musical. Baz,if you're reading this,you have all my sympathy. Thank you for making this picture.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Unlike Anything Ever Seen</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film has to be one of the most amazing, ambitious and beautiful films ever made. It captures the essence of a Red Curtain Production, and splashes it onto screen in dazzling, jaw-dropping fashion. The actor's talents and hard work is seen easily in this film, and director Baz Luhrmann has proved to be one of the most influential and creative filmmakers of his generation. Someone with so much vision could easily be called a genius, and it is disheartening to see that he was not nominated for "Best Director" by the Academy. If you have not seen this film already in theatres (which you have surely missed out), I cannot recommend it more for rental. The actors, director, everyone involved pulls you into the vivacious and vibrant world that is the Moulin Rouge, and makes the viewer never want to leave it. If the performance aspect is not quite fulfilling to one, the technical views should astonish some, with gutsy editing and the best costume, set and art direction I have seen to date. GO SEE THIS MOVIE!</fullReview>

		<date>2002-02-21</date>
		<username>David Nash (dbn3)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>It's Greatness Crept Up On Me (9/10)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(I saw this on DVD, YMMV)I haven't seen Luhrmann's other big film, Romeo+Juliet, nor did I know anything about the film when I rented it. All I had heard is that it was a musical, a bit odd, and nominated for some Oscars.Christian is a writer who gets drafted to write a play called Spectacular, Spectacular! when Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec (who is an actor, not a painter in this film) crashes through the ceiling with another actor practicing in the upstairs flat. Once the idea for the play is begun, the group of actors visit the Moulin Rouge to sell the play to the owner, Harold Zidler. There they meet Satine, a young dancer and prostitute that dreams of becoming a "real" actress someday. Here chance appears when the Duke of Monroth offers to finance Spectacular, Spectacular in return for Satine's services.The hook here is this movie is a musical. Not a typical musical, the songs here take lines and melodies from many different songs to create new ideas. The two pieces that stand out were the opening intro of the Moulin Rouge with the intro of Satine and the actors as they were waiting for Satine to save the play by acting her part for the Duke.The first had the women of the Moulin Rouge singing various lines from overtly sexual songs, with the men singing "here we are now, entertain us" from Nirvana. Ripped clean from it's cynical, ironic underpinnings, the line creates something totally new - call it the John's Anthem.The second had Christian singing a song of love and jealousy while the actors danced the life of a prostitute to "Roxanne" sung in a low growl.As I watched, I was increasingly impressed with the technique and with the ability of Kidman and McGregor to not get lost in all the music, color, and quick cuts. It was only at the end that I could look back and realize I had seen a great movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

It was a disappointment in general with some good moments and dynamic cinematography. The point is that it was flat but musical world with round bellies and lots of booze: Burgundian, flamboyant, bohemian, cancan and tragic. Tragic because the actors didn't have the chance to give the love story (which could have been good) sense.'Smells like teen spirit' (Nirvana), 'Your Song' (Elton John), 'Heroes' (David Bowie), 'One day I'll fly away', 'Roxanne' (Sting) and the inevitable 'The show must go on' (Queen) are examples of the arrangements for the score. The original songs once are great, but the rest of the movie didn't do much for me. I can understand the nostalghic feelings for those songs, but that doesn't really contribute to a great movie: it merely sets a firm tone and provides convenient dialogue from songtexts.The exclamation mark should have been removed from the title and especially from the movie itself if you take my meaning. Neither being a fan of Kidman and McGregor nor of musicals in general, I still say that Kidman and the cinematography deserve 2 B nominated, but no winners as far as I'm concerned. 6/10</fullReview>

		<date>2002-02-18</date>
		<username>Doug Phillips (janabro@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>`I'm paid to make men believe what they want to believe.'</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a `Cabaret' for the twenty-first century but without the original songs. Instead it builds on the work of other genius -- which leaves it somewhat hollow at the core. There is a great deal of genius -- here but it is borrowed genius: It is in the art direction, musical direction, lightening fast editing and the overall vision of director Baz Luhrmann. This film borrows from every known source: paintings, cartoons, with `Camille,' Satyricon,' and `Streetcar Named Desire' to name just a few of the film sources. Musically it is stunning. But even more stunning is how other people's music is used to tell this story -- a story originally told by Alexandre Dumas. The choreography is amazing; particularly the routine set to Sting's ?Roxanne.' It is jaw dropping.John Lequizamo, as Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, (especially when dressed as the ?sitar that could only tell the truth') is a brilliant piece of character acting.Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor do their own singing and they do it admirably.Everything is simplified: The Duke of Monroth (Richard Roxburgh) is evil. Christian (Ewan McGregor) is good and Nicole Kidman is the woman of easy virtue. It could hardly be more basic.The sets, costumes, makeup and overall visual feel of the film were outstanding. But there could be so much more.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Ho Hum</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First, let me say that I am Australian, love Australian movies, and admire the daring, new and exciting.Moulin Rouge delivers on some levels: The costuming is sumptuous There are witty gags through the music (especially loved the Like a Virgin scene) The acting is generally quite good Nicole Kidman is perfect for the role (I usually am not a fan of Nicole...)BUTI thought that the avant garde film making was hampered by a thin plot and weak dialogue. Come on, people, any film with the line, "You MUST sleep with the Duke" lacks sophistication. The underlying love story, though sweet, was very run-of-the-mill and seemed to be incidental to the theatrics.Moulin Rouge has made a stir, but I suspect that it will become one of those films that people forget as newer and better films come along. To give it credit, it has broken new ground - but I thought Madonna and 'Evita' was more sophisticated.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-02-18</date>
		<username>scarlet caulfield</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wow!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I walked out of the theater after seeing Moulin Rouge for the first time I was speechless. It took days for all I had just seen to sink in. I saw it two more times in the theaters and walked away always craving more. This film just "woke me up" so to speak and rejuvenated my spirits which were crushed by the mass-produced monotonous films of the season.Baz Luhrmann is a visual genius. He decided that he was going to spend millions of dollars making a lavish, all out, decadent, artistic musical experience. He could have spent this money making the next hallow Schwarzenegger film, but instead he decided to go out on a limb and a masterpiece was the final product.Some people have argued that this film merely shows glitz and glamour over substance, but I disagree. As he did with his version of Romeo and Juliet, Luhrmann has a way of using visual brilliance and music to convey emotions that could never be done with conventional filmmaking. The extraordinary artists, designers, and editors are the stars of the film, but the performers, especially Kidman, McGregor, and Broadbent steal the show.The songs are incredible too. Only Luhrmann could combine Nirvana, Queen, Elton John and other pop figures into one giant montage of artistic vision. It feels as though the songs were written for the movie, as they work perfectly with each scene, and the stars can sing beautifully too!This film is a work of love. It is obvious that everyone who was involved with the picture took it to heart. The story I'll admit is not original - in fact it's very similar to Romeo and Juliet, a story which has been beaten to the ground at this point. But the film is still very original as it takes the feelings and emotions of love and splashes them across the screen in every scene. In the first half of the film we see the mystical world of Bohemia through the eyes of Christian who is in love. Much like in Romeo and Juliet, during the second half the mood changes leading up to an emotional climax.However, it is when he is in love that Bohemia sparkles, showing how love can change everything. This film is essentially a tribute to the power of love to change one's world.I suggest that you watch this film with an open mind and an open heart, and just let yourself fall into this irrational glittering world of Bohemia during the "summer of love." You too will fall in love with Luhrmann's style, trust me.</fullReview>
	</review>

I suppose being used to his style made it easier for me to fall in love with the film, viewers seem to either love it fiercely or hate it with a passion.As others have mentioned, the story is simple yet touching. The score is amazingly blended into the film's musical numbers and it's nearly impossible not to find yourself singing along in your repeat viewings. Watch out for Ewan McGregor's sudden outbursts of song, they're beautiful and breathtaking. He plays his role exceptionally well, his face perfectly capturing that of the innocent man untouched by the cruel machinations of Love. I was *very* surprised with his singing ability.Nicole Kidman is even better. I was shocked at how stunningly beautiful she is. I could have lived with fewer poodle yips from her, but other than that I thought she was amazing, I now have a new favorite for Best Actress when March 24 comes around! Next time I'm at Amazon, I will be sure to buy this, I have a feeling I won't get tired of it.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-02-14</date>
		<username>Mercy Bell (mercybell)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brilliance and Beauty behind Insanity</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"This story is about love...the woman I loved is.....dead." That's one of the first lines of this film, and sets the tone better than you could imagine. You might think it sets you up for a depressing ride...ha. You either love it or hate it, I've never met anyone in the middle.This is a better movie than I imagined. It sells itself as a colorful melodrama, but it's a musical through and through. It's officially a TragiComiDramaMusical, or that's what the critics call it, but it gets to your heartstrings and senses and kicks them - violently.Baz Luhrmann had a theory for this film, that music and razzle dazzle and color will create a heightened experience, and it worked. People may pay more attention to it for it's astounding technical abilities. But then I was mainly captivated by it's music, acting, and it's storyline. Not to say I didn't like the color and razor sharp editing (Jill Bilcock is quite amazing), quite the contrary. I was purely amazed at what they achieved. But that they could go over that and send a clear cut and emotional story with superb acting, is something you rarely see in any "super charged" films. It's chock full of allegories, symbolism, etc, of which we rarely see anymore, and there are many layered stories occurring at once. Luhrmann hand groomed it all to make it work at it's full potential, and it's varying degrees of beauty will hit you if you really pay attention. This is not a film to be watched partly, you have to pay full attention or you won't get it.The story is loosely based on the Greek Tragedy about Orhpeus and Dumas'fils "Camille". It revolves around the young Christian (Ewan McGregor) who enters the world of the Moulin Rouge and Montmarte to become a great writer. He befriends some strange Bohemians and is assigned to write a show for the MR called "Spectacular! Spectacular!". He has to recruit the courtesan Satine, but falls in love with her. Eventually they both become enmeshed in their love for each other, the dirty and treacherous goings on of the MR, and the making of the show. After betrayal and intrigue, the film ends with a tragic ending you knew was coming from Christian's first penetrating line: "This story is about love...the woman I loved is.....dead."The acting is much better than I expected. People had been talking about how Kidman could get a Oscar nomination for her performance in this (which she did), but I had thought "Why? It's a musical. There's no such thing as good acting in musicals." Nicole shines. She goes through several stages in the film and is always believable at the level she chooses. Especially in her TB scenes, where she plays sick, she does a very unglamorous and ugly portrayal of the disease. She does comedy and seduction and heroism in one role subtly, and it's not at all cliche. McGregor particularly surprised me. I had known he was a good actor, he too goes through stages, and pulls it off with his ability to act completly natural in a weird role. It's hard to act "innocent" without getting terribly annoying, and he's not, but maybe because he's more of a decent and noble character than the stereotypical "innocent" (compared to Dumas' Armand, he's far nobler, he doesn't sink to depravity whereas Armand did). Supporting characters shine, and John Leguizamo deserves a thumbs up for a particularly painful but strong performance (if you hear how they shortened him). Jim Broadbent, who plays the enabling and sweet pimp Zidler (that's what he is), is fantastic, and Richard Roxborough who plays the Duke is notorious and does a wonderful job at being completely and one hundred percent devious.This movie shines, and it addicts you. Many people have said you either love it or you hate it, and I'd say it's true, I've never met someone who was lukewarm about it. It will either overwhelm you or you'll find it ridiculous, or you'll like it for all it is. It's supposed to be overboard. It's supposed to have that "If it exists we'll use it just because." That's the whole point. It's a beautiful film, and it's very true in it's story, it follows how life works. There are people who'll be bad to you, and people who will love you, and not everything works as you want it and death is a much stronger force than an ideal. It's supposed to be an experience, not just a date at the movies. © written by Mercy Bell</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-02-14</date>
		<username>RHPSvegas</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A work of art bashed due to ignorance on the viewer's part</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After carefully reading the previous comments I have come to theconclusion that the people who don't like this movie are one of twotypes: 1.They didn't understand it or 2.they are so self-absorbed withdiscrediting everything that they lack the ability to find the beauty insomething that truly exists therein. That's all I really have to say.Just because you don't like something, don't knock it. Also, this moviemust be seen in its 2.35:1 theatrical aspect ratio IN A THEATRE to fullydo the film justice. 	<review>
		<date>2002-02-14</date>
		<username>elanor_1421</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>very brave. very beautiful to look at. acting's not too bad.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I can't remember much of my first viewing of this film - only that I was dead to the world outside of "Moulin Rouge", had some kind of goofy smile plastered on my face all the way through and that my head was reeling by the end. I had come, after steeling myself for disappointment, to be pleasantly surprised and moved - not by the plot or acting, it must be admitted, but by the sheer visual impact of the film and the evident enthusiasm with which it was made. It's a gutsy production, and I admired baz for taking it on. It was not until later viewings (when I finally had room in my brain to process something other than the intoxicating sets, costumes and songs) that I began to appreciate the acting and the plot. Kidman's performance, in particular, had left me strangely cold after the first viewing, while I found McGregor adorable in the wide-eyed innocent role. It is only later, when I finally became familiar with the character of Satine, that I realised Kidman actually turns out a better, more delicate and subtle performance than McGregor. Her character is far more complex and underneath the surface, far more intense, and must have been a greater challenge. Satine is Christian's first love - he will eventually move on. But for Satine, more world-weary, Christian is her first, last, and only chance at living a life with love. All her emotion is invested in this relationship - it is her key to freedom. So, while the plot is simple, classic (and on first viewing appears cliched), it is still a powerful story, pulled off by some pretty decent performances from its actors. After watching the film a few times, you realise that a more complex or even more unfamiliar plot would have made the whole thing into a REAL mess - it would have been too much to juggle and sustain along with all the stylistic elements which, let's face it, make the movie. 1(for plot) +3 (for acting) +5 (for creativity and courage to try something fresh and original)= 9/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

I will class this as a rare sample of fine cinema, and will dare to compare it with other masters of the kind like Evita and Grease. The addition of a tragic ending 'amour', has given the film a touch of 'Love Story', with Ryan O'Neal and Ali Mc Graw.There's only one verdict. Get it and treasure it. 15/10!</fullReview>

The screen explodes with vibrant colors, song, dance, and of course, the gorgeous, talented and utterly unpredictable stunner NICOLE KIDMAN. This really looks like a labor of love for all involved and it is just pure escapism, the sort of film movies are made for. I agree with those who claim the story is simple, but it needs to be, because the screen is bursting with life and a complex story would just make things too difficult to grasp. 		<date>2002-02-13</date>
		<username>sash_hockey (sash_hockey@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A visual blast</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie excels at what it intends to do... it's la boheme spirit in it's funniest form. Surely, the story line is predictable... but then, it was never supposed to be surprising (Christian tells you in the setup how the story will end...), so, instead of predictable, the appropriate term should be 'classic' - I would not go so far as to call it Shakespearan, though. It has so many references, grand musical performances, dazzling visuals and great camera work that it at least qualifies as number one musical I have seen so far... because it is essentially light-hearted. I am a huge fan of production values, after all, that's what makes most of a movie truly appealing, and Moulin Rouge had it all. The set design was great, the acting very solid, the singing surprisingly good, the direction flawless, the camera work dazzling, the FX fun, the dancing intriguing. It surely is not the most important movie of the century, but if you are willingly to let it pick you up and be carried away by it, this movie will make you want to see it again and again... Conclusion: Spectacular Spectacular, straight A for production values, worth the DVD buy anytime.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-02-09</date>
		<username>Kim</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>I Might Not Be Musically Inclined But.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am going to compare `Moulin Rouge' with `Shakespeare In Love' because both of the movies are about a struggling young man and a stunning(and stunningly skinny) beauty sought by a wealthy and callous other man. Both movies are about the love between a writer and a performer within a play. And both movies represent young love with physical passion and sexy young stars. I admit, the movies cannot be compared in movie making ability, because the styles are so different (MR is more creative visually and stylistically, but SIL is more creative with language, and incorporating-and changing history), but they can be compared on their representations of love. SIL actually is better at showing true love than MR. SIL's love affair makes MR's look like over-dramatic puppy love.First, the scenes between Christian and Satine in MR don't display as much love on a intellectual-as well as physical level-as the scenes between Viola and Shakespeare. Viola's intellect is comparable to Shakespeare's. Viola is actually more realistic than Shakespeare. She realizes-before him-that she can cherish what she has with Shakespeare forever, but must marry Wessex in order to allow Shakespeare to continue to create what they both love-plays. Indeed, their love is based on a greater love. In MR, Christian seems somewhat educated, but Satine doesn't even realize that coughing up blood means you are going to die-especially without treatment. Not that Viola and Shakespeare give the impression of intertwined souls, but Christian and Satine just seemed like merely horn dogs who substitute dramatic posturing for love and still think it's the same thing. Viola and Shakespeare really cared about the play they were creating; they truly wanted to create something together that other people would truly care about. Christian and Satine created a half-baked play to bolster Satine's career and protect their affair from the duke's immense `intellect.' Both Christian and Shakespeare were on deadlines but Shakespeare actually cared what he was writing about.I guess one could argue that Christian and Satine shared a love for the Moulin Rouge, since they were only shown to love another within the vicinity of the Moulin Rouge. But that means that Viola and Shakespeare's love was even more varied. They not only love each other in the playhouse and Viola's bedroom, but outside a church and beside a river. They did not need a certain surrounding to support their love. Shakespeare didn't care if Viola looked like a woman when he kissed her either. That either shows true love-or Shakespeare was really horny or kinky or both.Another argument is that love cannot include jealousy. The Bible does mention that love is not envious. Shakespeare is never jealous when Viola is involved. (He is only jealous of Marlowe.) He knows she loves him and not Wessex. What says more about love than when a person trusts the person they love enough not to be jealous? In MR though, Christian gets jealous of the Duke because he doesn't trust Satine's love for him. (Which is incredibly stupid of him because why would Satine even like a dolt like the Duke? Maybe Christian and Satine are an intellectual match after all.)Another thing-Viola wanted to act because she loved it. She didn't even care about the recognition because she acted under the name of Thomas Kent. Satine on the other hand, wanted to act to be a `star.' Which character shows more true love and passion? (This argument assumes people think passion for oneself is not as noble as passion for creativity and other people.)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A Visual masterpiece</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just watched Moulin Rouge for the fourth time. I am more amazed each time I see it...each time I hear the soundtrack. I am a photographer so light, color, and their combinations fascinate me. As I viewed the film the first time...I was blown away at the introduction to the Moulin Rouge....the smearing,swirling of color...the quick cut editing...the wild music and bacchanalian fever of the sequence made me feel as if I was walking through there myself...that scene...with the Lady Marmalade song by the "ladies" and the rich men entering with Smells like Teen Spirit....sold me then and there regardless of having to get over my dislike of all things Kidman...after my third viewing she had won me over as well. Try as I might I cannot picture anyone else in the role. The Roxanne number was so perfect to the mood of the story at the moment and what better way in which to tell it but the over the top tango...at once violent...sensual...dramatic....and true to the storyline at the moment I have a weakness for the romantic movie but am also a movie snob and this film filled both bills for me.Congrats to Mr. Luhrmann.</fullReview>

		<username>upjchick286 (upjchick286@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>One in a million!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For those who think of this film as a disaster, do not have any sense of art. It is just like those people who do not understand what is so intriguing about a dark hard to see image on canvas, you have no understanding. Ah yet people are entitled to their own opinions, my request is to sit down and think. Put yourself in the place of that particular person. The film was nothing less than extraordinary, superb, spectacular spectacular. Never will you ever see a film quit like this. I must say I was taken back at first, but yet I watched on and after it made me think. Never have I seen two actors draw you into a film like these two did. Never have I felt as if I was personally there and felt their pain along with their love. I've watched it over and over again, only to find out more about the film. This is and will be one of the greatest films made. No film can make you laugh and cry the way this one can. Do not watch the film for pure entertainment; watch the film to be put into the film. It almost makes you feel as if you can not live your life locked away... you never know when your life could be taken next, it makes you appreciate people and loved ones more, especially significant others... my request is to sit down watch it and be involved, then you'll understand why those who love the film love it.</fullReview>

		<username>Lady Jasmine</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I own the DVD set of this movie, and it is an addition to my growing collection I will never regret. It took me twice to the theatre to really understand this movie...but I came out loving it both times, the second time I just loved it more. It is not exactly what I would classify as a spectacular movie musical...for that you have to back to the classics, but it has an undeniable appeal all it's own. I have heard a lot of people say to me that this movie plays like a music video, that the songs are fit oddly into the story and many other things. But, after years of seeing musicals and being in them, I have to wonder if there is a single musical out there that doesn't have people randomly bursting into song at odd times (see the Gotta Dance number in Singing in the Rain if you don't believe me). This movie is not meant to be logical, it's meant to be a moving, dazzling, tantalizing appeal to all the senses, and in that it succeeds remarkably.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-02-02</date>
		<username>stacy_g_ie</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>What can I say in one line that will summarise this masterpiece?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Q. What's Moulin Rouge all about, then?A.It's about a young English poet named Christian (Ewan McGregor, whose performance has been highly under-rated) who travels to Paris in 1899, despite his father's disapproval. He becomes acquainted with Henri Toulouse-Laudrec (John Leguizamo), a disorientated Argentinean (Jacek Koman), and several others. Well, they fall through his roof anyway. When they discover he is a writer, they want him to write a play, then get it staged in La Mouline Rouge (Translates as "The Red Windmill")"The Nightclub of Your Dreams!" It is there he first sees Satine (Nicole Kidman) a beautiful, ahem, courtesan. They meet, fall in love, sing and dance...but all is not well. The Duke of Monroth (Richard Roxburgh) is determined to take Satine away from the Moulin Rouge and make her a star (and, it seems, his wife). But then Harold Zidler (Jim Broadbent) our nightclub's manager, discovers that our Satine is not very well... This is a beautiful film. (C'est Magnifique!)Anyone who says this is just like all the other films titled 'Moulin Rouge' (the flops from the 30's and 40's,) either cannot appreciate good things, or is lying. Running at just over 2 hours, some would say it's a little long, but it flies by with the help of some speedy cameras and beautiful performances. With some help from a few familiar songs (Heroes by David Bowie, Material Girl by Madonna, and Your Song by Sir Elton John, to name a few) and obvious hard work, Baz Luhramann has created the best musical since Grease. (C'mon, admit it, we all sang Summer Nights at one point) All the stars positively sparkle and there is strong chemistry between them all. There are times when you laugh (When Zidler sings a famous Madonna reel to the Duke) times when you cry (The tragedy off-stage about ten minutes before the end, I'm not gonna spoil it for the minority who haven't seen it) and times when you can only sit on the edge of your seat to see what happens (yeah, like I'm going to tell you when that is! ). It'll be a few months before the launch of Moulin Rouge on DVD over here, but if you're in a similar situation, it's totally worth waiting for. Someone asked me why the actors in this were so great. Y'know what I said?`BECAUSE THEY CAN CAN-CAN!' (Sorry for the bad joke.)Stacy_G_IE</fullReview>
	</review>
