	<review>
		<date>2001-11-13</date>
		<username>stamper</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A Marvel of sights and sounds</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** This film, set in 1899 is really one of the most original films for years, that has big names and big bucks in it. I must say I was really astonished in how Baz Luhrmann was able to merge the feeling of a 1899 nightclub with modern 20th century music. I mean there were so many modern love songs mingled into the story and singing, I sometimes wondered if the writers had come up with anything of their own. But disregarding the fact that they were all existing songs I have to admire the way they were integrated into this film. That was really a job well done. First of all (for most of them and the ones I recognized) they were rearranged and then the parts were sung by actors and/or some singers. Then there was the enormous variety of genre's the songs were from, without even disturbing one another. I mean there was grunge, soul, pop and rock, with songs like (QUEEN - The Show Must go On; THE POLICE - Roxanne; THE BEATLES - All you need is Love; MADONNA - Material Girl and Like A Virgin; WHITNEY HOUSTON - I'll Always Love You; NIRVANA - Smells Like Teen Spirit; KISS - I Was Made For Loving You; DAVID BOWIE - Heroes and PATTI LA BELLE - Lady Marmalade). I only list the songs I recognized (and remembered) and their original artists as far as I can remember them, because I do not know who sang them in the film. The mingling of these various popular and famous songs of different genre's into a film about a brothel in the late 20th century is an accomplishment of itself.As in regards to the story, I feel there is nothing much to say, first of all it is a film about love. And one with a tragic ending (no spoilers here, because Ewan McGregor will reveal this himself within the first 5 minutes of the film). For this it is comparable with the 3 greatest love stories ever told in history (GONE WITH THE WIND, TITANIC and DRACULA). It just has everything to become an instant classic. It is set (as the other three films) in a time where there is no (or not much) electricity and that gives it something of 'the good old days' feeling with a bit of a more romantic feeling, for that was the time when men were still gentlemen and romanticism had it's peak.As far as the film goes there are three things that stand out. First of all the direction of Baz Luhrmann, who (again) after Romeo and Juliet succeeded in giving a story set in the past something of a modern look. His vision and direction of this story is really great and combines to make this the sights and sounds spectacle it eventually came to be (Oscar nominee for directing I guess, but no award).Then there are the decorations and the costumes, which are really great and visually so demanding that you become lost in them and are thereby dragged into this romantic, humorous and tragic musical of epic proportions (An Oscar for costumes and a nomination for Art Direction / Set decoration)Well, as should be done in a film, I saved the highlight for last. The best thing about this film is.....Nicole Kidman. No offense to the other actors who all did a good job, but she really outshone everyone of them, she was superb, magnificent, extraordinary simply put she was just GREAT. She was very, very convincing as the courtesan that wished to be more, that wished to fly away but.well I'm not revealing more than the first five minutes of film do.dies in the end. With that in mind one might predict the ending (as I somehow did) and not like this film, due to predictability. I mean I am not saying that this film should get an award (or even a nomination) for best story or screenplay. No, what I am saying is that this film is so visually exciting and gripping that it overcomes predictability and surges to a highpoint, only to be picked up by Nicole Kidman who takes this film even higher to the top of the mountain, to greatness. Despite that I'm not saying that this film landed on the highest mountain ever, but it sure is in the area nearest to the moon and stars. Leaving behind any movie I've seen this year. Therefore it is in my opinion unavoidable that this film will get the Oscar for best movie (I know it somehow will). For it is by far the best movie of the year 2001.And the Oscar for best actress goes to (well it will anyway): NICOLE KIDMAN (standing ovations please!!!)8,5 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I usually don't like musicals. I've never liked the fact that people start to sing when I least expect it (and least want them to). I guess I like Moulin Rouge since it's so crazy that the singing doesn't seem as unnatural as in other films.Moulin Rouge is first and foremost a feast for the eyes. The production design is spectacular as is the costume design. The visual effects are brilliant. It's colourful and dazzling. It feels original. The premise of the movie is not original at all, a classic story of doomed love. For once, though, I didn't think about the fact that the premise is so archetypical, I was too busy watching the screen.Both Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman, as well as most of the supporting players, are brilliant. Moulin Rouge is a crazy and beautiful film. (7/10)</fullReview>

		<date>2001-11-10</date>
		<username>aumanj</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wow, what a Movie!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moulin Rouge is by far one of the best movies of the early 21st century. It should set standards for movies and musicals to come. The imagery, graphics, costumes and emotions were all real and quite amazing. The costumes were certainly on the money for the times of the day. The acting by Nicole and Ewan and cast were wonderful and very believable. The sets and style in which this movie was filmed was so original and unique. There is simply no way to describe it really. One must see it! Only a few things bothered me, and they were minor compared to acting and special effects which made up for it. Warning this may be a spoiler to some but I will keep it as generic as possible.!For the most part the music was great and quite funny at times. However, I was expecting more original tunes, like ALL of most musicals have. Tunes from the 1980's really doesn't fit in the 1900's style of music for that day. I was a little disappointed in the tune by Madonna and Sting re-arranged as it were. Maybe it's an honor to use another star's tunes, but I it's hard to beat the original. But in reality, the arrangements of their tunes were so funny, which made it easy to look over and try to focus on the very upbeat and gripping love story taking place. Trust me, there is no room for boredom in this flick. The special effects were truly amazing and realistic.!!I do love musicals and this one is truly one to start a genre or revival of musicals for the 21st century, hopefully. One other thing, Toulousse Lautrec was played well by Leguizamo, but I was looking forward to seeing some of his art portrayed in the movie as well as the story line be more based on his character. Being an art lover also, one can imagine my disappointment when no beautiful impressionistic art was to be seen throughout the movie. However, the costumes were so up to date for the early 1900s that this helped me imagine the artwork Lautrec was painting, and what inspired him during those tumultuous times in Paris during his day.Anyway this one is definitely 8 out of 10 stars. It would be a ten if not for the pop music and more story on Lautrec! Great movie, definitely in top 5 of 2001!Go see it to believe it and just sit back and try to absorb everything that is being thrown at you at you once. What a RIDE! Go Nicole and Ewan, you guys rule!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-11-10</date>
		<username>Karen Proffitt</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A wonderfully stirring, funny, emotive and original film.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wasn't quite sure what to expect when I went to the cinema to see "Moulin Rouge". I should have known that the superlative Baz Luhrmann would not disappoint his fans(I speak as an English teacher who has seen even the most resistant pupils warm to "Romeo &amp; Juliet" through his film version.)The golden age of musicals would seem to be long gone(apart from many wonderful Disney animations). Well this statement I am pleased to say is no longer true!What an absolutely wonderful cinematic experience this film was. I viewed this film with my Mum (67 years old) and my ten year old son who's an ADHD sufferer and he could not take his eyes off the screen! Three different generations were thrilled by the songs, the colour and the fine acting of both the leading and supporting actors. There is a clear chemistry between Nicole Kidman and Ewan Mcgregor and you always sympathise with their characters and the trials and tribulations that they face in the story. Their wonderful singing voices and clever choice of songs (Elton John's "Your Song" takes on a whole new life)only add to the illusion that they are a couple deeply and genuinely in love. The course of true love never did run smooth and you can almost imagine the Duke twirling his moustache like the stereotypical baddie. However, this film never turns into parody.There are many witty and humorous sections(watch out for Ewan and Nicole's first encounter where Ewan only wants to read poetry to the gorgeous Satine)and both stars display comic timing very different from many of the cinematic roles they are most famous for.Ewan is an absolute babe and Nicole stunning in a variety of outfits which show off her endless legs (I am sooo jealous!!! Tom Cruise YOU MUST BE MAD!)This film would stand with such fine classic musicals as "The King and I" and "South Pacific" and the addition of many contemporary songs pleased both an eighties chick and a current chart fan. The twists and turns of the plot and the visual feast for the viewer meant that this film was never predictable and with a story line (that could easily have turned into schmaltz) to tug at even the hardest heart, this is a must see for everyone.An absolute triumph!! Forget the usual boring, predictable films turned out by Hollywood and go and see something which will restore your faith in the power and magic of cinema at its best.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-11-08</date>
		<username>pkanzow</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Spectacular! Must see!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay, this movie has a trivial plot and no realism but that's not the point because it is a SHOW. It is not even about a show, it IS one.The beginning already shows this - the canvas becomes a curtain, with a conductor in front - you're not watching a stroy about the Moulin Rouge, you're sitting in the Moulin Rouge.The movie is not even trying to move you to the fin the siecle, to the early 1900's, to show you an historic show. NO, it's a show of TODAY, with TODAY's songs (songs of the 60's to 90's which did not exist in 1900 when the movie "takes place").So stop thinking. Just relax, and enjoy this extraordinary audiovisual experience. This is one of the movies that trade in realism for being an artwork, and that I like very much. The flying views of the city reminded me of "The Crow" and other comic strip movies, like "Batman" and "Dick Tracy". I love this kind of somewhat strange athomsphere.And I loved hearing well known songs in surprising arrangements, like "Roxanne", "The Show Must Go On", even "I Was Made For Loving You" sung by this elf, Nicole Kidman, instead of these "horror-masked" bad boys of KISS.I totally fell in love with this unique artwork, and gave it a 9/10. The missing 10th is due to I think it could have been done better, if you got the best singers/actors of the world which Kidman and McGregor are not. But without doubt they did a good job and I was surprised how well "Obi-wan Kenobi" can sing. And I pity Tom Cruise for losing this breathtaking wonderful woman, Nicole Kidman.A must see for everyone who loves musicals, romance and bizarre, fast-paced pictures. One of the best movies in 2001.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-11-07</date>
		<username>stevenleadbetter</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Film Of The Year?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It started and I was surprised, it was nothing like I was expecting. Ewan McGregor? Singing? This can't be right..Still, it appeared to be happening, whether my eyes believed it or not. Once you get used to the fact that it is set in the Moulin Rouge in 1899/1900 but they still appear to be singing Elton John and Police numbers, you can begin to enjoy the film itself. Don't let this fact put you off, the songs that have been chosen (and there are many) have been done with consummate care and attention and all work excellently well in a setting you would not expect them too. 'Like A Virgin' being quite marvelous in particular. McGregor plays an Englishman arriving in Paris in the Summer of 1899, to live life hedonistically with the Bohemians of the time. He writes a play to be performed at the Moulin Rouge by their resident cast, lead actress of which is Nicole Kidman, who actually glows in her role. She shows off her more than capable singing voice. Supported by an excellent all singing, all dancing cast of what appears to number hundreds. Some wonderful camera shots, a dramatic score that tingles on the back of your neck in parts and casting that would appear to be close to perfection, this is clearly (and by some margin) the best of the bunch thus far. Glorious, decadent, witty, fascinating and tragic. Absolutely delightful.</fullReview>
	</review>

Although Baz Luhrmann's creative style may not agree with everyone, it's worth a watch (or six) - if only to hear Ewan McGregor sing!</fullReview>

		<username>Bob-785</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wow!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is amazing! This is one of the best films I have ever seen. Every time I watch it, I notice something that I didn't see before. Every aspect of the film fits together, there is no moment that makes you think 'That doesn't fit' or 'I don't think he/she would react like that'. The fast moving, surrealistic approach was superb and Luhrmann got it spot on. The chemistry between Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman was brilliant. They were so convincingly in love. The entire cast was brilliant, particularly Jim Broadbent and John Lequizamo as Toulouse-Lautrec. And Kylie's cameo as The Green Fairy was brilliant. I laughed hysterically, I cried my eyes out, I basically fell in love with all the characters. I would recommend this film to anyone who believes in freedom, beauty, truth and love.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-11-03</date>
		<username>colcam</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Too clean</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Too clean, too pretty, too nice---This was an ugly, dirty era, and a bitter, nasty time in the era, but somehow, even as our central figures suffer disease, cough up blood, and generally display ill health we wind up with a painting of light that manages to ignore the bitter ugliness of the era.If it had been a bit dirtier, if we had seen that even the rich were forced to scratch their lice, if the ugly undertones of adult and child prostitution had been shown more clearly it would have been more understandable why they were willing go to such extremes to escape a hopeless life "at the fringe" of society.You cannot fault the actors; you can fault the writers and producers for not making sure the ugly was included-- and then contrasting the beautiful, although doomed, against it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-11-02</date>
		<username>meitschi</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A superb reappropriation of classical musical</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A wonderful reworking of the classical film musical of the 1940s and 50s (like "An American in Paris"), "updated" for younger generations. It blends a very sentimental, but touching story, familiar songs, and a 50s musical setting with a visual esthetic reminding that of video clips. The film is based essentially on the fact that the viewer already knows all the elements of it (we know from the first scene on how the story will end, the setting, characters, and occurring conflicts are familiar, as is the music). The film seems to aim to be the "non plus ultra" of film musical, it contains everything this genre - as well as other, related genres like video clips, revue movies, historic melodramas, and even animated Disney flicks (check out the green fairy scene or the singing moon!) - have to offer. It succeeds in this in an amazing way, due to the perfect screenplay, the good choice of music, the absolutely wonderful photography (has any actress ever seemed so beautiful on film as Nicole Kidman does here?!), and the stunning editing. A must-see, especially for those who are interested in film history and like to be overwhelmed by the visual richness of a movie.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-11-01</date>
		<username>ProperCharlie</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Spectacular, Spectacular</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**SPOILERS ARE CONTAINED HEREIN. BEWARE FOOLHARDY READERS!**You know if you take out the songs, slow down the editing, keep the heroine alive at the end, split the Duke into two characters (the Money and the Evil Love Interest), send it back in time by about 250 years and move it about 200 miles or so North West and you've got Shakespeare in Love.Moulin Rouge isn't an original film, it doesn't have an original editing style, it doesn't have original songs, the acting is good but not great, the singing *is* great although the comedy can grate, and the plot is seemingly ripped from another film which mimics another story (already covered by Baz) and that is being taken to court for plagiarism (did you follow that?)What Moulin Rouge is however, is *magic*.Magic is what cinema is all about. A piece of cinema can be original with excellent score, acting, direction, cinematography, script and all the rest but still not light up that part of you that will stay glowing and warm all the way through a tortuous tube trip home.I'm still smiling now and my whole being is suffused with a warm fuzzy feeling that I don't want to let go of.Leave your intellect at the door, prepare to be smacked round the chops by visuals that will blind you as completely as prolonged absinthe use, and let your ears fill with at least three of the past thirty years more popular songs being sung at the same time and at immense volume. 10/10Shakespeare in Love got lots of Oscars. I wonder what the Academy will make of this?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-11-01</date>
		<username>elestor</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The Greatest Musical Ever Made</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After seeing Moulin Rouge I could only think Baz Luhrmann wanted to make the most spectacular, spectacular musical ever. And the only way to do this is on celluloid, because the music, the sets, the effects, everything is just too darn 'big' to perform on stage. A masterfully crafted film, every second must have taken careful planning and shooting. This film is a rollercoasterride of emotions, it starts of very high paced and comedial (is that a word?), then it becomes grand and romantic and ends in deep, deep tragedy. I was absolutely thrilled! Fantastic music, I bought the soundtrack the day after. If this film doesn't get the academy award for best music, than I'll eat my top hat!I voted 9 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-10-29</date>
		<username>Brodie_500</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Ambitious, engrossing spectacle.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moulin Rouge is what it sets out to be: a dazzling, colourful, exuberant celebration of bohemia and song. Normally, such glossy, seemingly shallow fare would best be avoided, but Moulin Rouge is an exception. And a damn good one at that.*small spoilers*Ewan McGregor is Christian, a romantic young poet with a knack for improvising song lyrics, a talent that brings him (via some drunken bohemians) to the Moulin Rouge - a nightclub for the rich and the beautiful, a whirlwind of sex and glamour. After a case of (that old screwball chestnut) mistaken identity, Christian ends up inadvertently falling for (and winning over) the queen bee of the Moulin Rouge - Nicole Kidman's courtesan Satine. Their romance is cemented in a visually stunning (and well sung) performance of Elton John's 'Your Song', but (as with all romances) their love is threatened, in this case by a whining rodent of a Duke (Richard Roxburgh). He wants Satine and seeing as Zidler (Jim Broadbent), the owner of the Moulin Rouge, needs the Duke's financing, he agrees to hand his star attraction over.The narrative is as dull and unoriginal as that. As far as the story is concerned, Moulin Rouge is poor. But this, surprisingly, doesn't seem to matter much. The story is secondary, a mere backdrop for Luhrmann to stage extraordinary musical numbers, and to display a range of emotions in the most glamorous and dazzling ways possible. If his attempts at doing so had fallen flat (none do), then this film would have been disastrous, like a 'Rocky Horror Picture Show' without the wryness and the controversy.Luhrmann delivered us an overly familiar story for a reason: this film is so packed with music, song, extravagant camera angles and sheer personality that an original story could have been overload. What Luhrmann has given us instead is a fantastic, original idea. The anachronistic use of familiar music is a pure success. The sentiments of each song represent what the Moulin Rouge was; a place of freedom, energy and lust (this is best shown in the introduction to the nightclub, when Luhrmann splices 'Smells Like Teen Spirit', 'Lady Marmalade' and 'Diamond Dogs' with a manic reworking of the Can Can).The film's unrelenting energy may overwhelm some, and it NEVER lets up. This can be seen as a virtue, but if you're unprepared for it, it could work the other way.Whether you love Moulin Rouge for its anachronism and explosiveness, or if you hate it, it can't be denied that Moulin Rouge is made by people with talent and vision. Luhrmann puts on a grand show, and his actors serve him very well indeed.Roxburgh copes well with the cliched Duke, while Broadbent is completely charismatic as Zidler. In the leads, Kidman and McGregor are outstanding. Although her vocals shake on the odd occasion, Kidman demands to be watched - her startling rendition of 'Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend' is magnificent, reminiscent of Marlene Dietrich, but she gleefully ditches the sophistication when she partakes wonderfully in the impromptu song-and-dance pitch for a play. McGregor is also enchanting as he perfectly captures the dreamy-eyed, romantic optimism of Christian. His voice is stunning, and he is an ideal hero. Broadbent, Kidman and McGregor all deserve Oscar noms for their work, and I wouldn't be surprised if Kidman takes one home.Other scenes to watch out for: the wonderfully executed tango to 'Roxanne', the show-stopping 'Like A Virgin' routine, a witty exchange of song lyrics between Kidman &amp; McGregor atop a huge bejewelled elephant, and an hilarious cameo from Kylie Minogue as a green sprite with a fondness for 'The Sound of Music'.Moulin Rouge takes advantage of the magic of cinema, a concept that is so often talked about, but rarely used with such conviction, originality and ambition. Allow it it's flaws, and appreciate its many virtues - a great show.10/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-10-29</date>
		<username>Morten Ek</username>
		<score>0.9</score>

	</review>

Allow it it's flaws, and appreciate its many virtues - a great show.10/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>parrot99</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Like two movies in one</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The problem I had with Moulin Rouge is that it almost seems like Luhrmann shot two movies - one good, one bad - and had a blind person splice them together. The romance between McGregor and Kidman is very good, the chemistry is excellent. Their stuff works. What doesn't is the over the top musical numbers, especially the "Like A Virgin" number - oy, vey what was Baz thinking on that one? Cut about one-third of the musical numbers and the movie would rate around an 8.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-10-27</date>
		<username>(albechri@bdg.centrin.net.id)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Windmills of the Gods</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The musical journey of love was never this colourful. Unique andyet original, Moulin Rouge splash an episode of a writer (EwanMac Gregor) who fall in love with a top-notch beauty Satine (NicoleKidman).The satire and yet surrealis mode of the lavishing beauty ofeveryday life in Bohemian style was carefully carved and decoratedwith enormous collections of modern music adaptation. There-arrangement and restructuring of the musical compilationsproven to be relevant yet powerful to enhance the storyline andsparkling romance.It is a tragic fairy tale, so expect some unusual acts and turmoil,the movie was made specifically to glorious love, and only deathwhich can separate it but won't destroy it. The mood, the acts, theplots, expect not much from the casts, but the movie is still verymuch enjoyable.Take a close look towards the musical score, it is actually had abiggest grip towards building the emotions throughout the movie,and indeed it explodes in the credit title.A must for fantasy musical romance movie goers... a highlyrecommended movie to enjoy throughout the time.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-10-27</date>
		<username>Stephen Galloway</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Thank you Baz Luhrmann</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's hard to put into words the true beauty of the film "Moulin Rouge". It is, for want of a better word, a masterpiece. In an age of movie mania where all movies seem to contain at least some similarites to the others. Moulin Rouge has broken this trend and it has done so in a way that is simply breathtaking. When I sat down to watch this film... I imagined it would simply be an all sining, all dancing musical converted into a film in order to attract a larger audience. How wrong I was. This film was a beautiful congregation of passion, love,faith, hope and, indeed, all things bohemian. The acting was superb. The singing was unbelievably moving. (Especially the duets between Kidman and McGregor). The writing was touching yet comical when the need for a break in the emotion was called for. However, the best aspect of the film by far was the amazing talent of the great Baz Luhrmann (Director). He brought every single bit of action and emotion to the audience. He allowed us all to feel emotions that the characters themselves were feeling. This, at times, brought many in the screen to tears. It takes a lot of talent to make a good film but everyone involved in this film deserves the recognition they deserve because, though somehow missed by the American critics, this film is a true classic. One thats legacy will most probably outlive it's stars and rightly so. Moulin Rouge is a modern day masterpiece. It is funny. Moving. Emotional. If you are one of these people who likes to look for flaws in films. You'll have to look very hard when watching this film. For those of you who are looking for a good night out. Turn down the lights. Open the wine. Bring in the popcorn and cuddle up to your partner because buy the end, You'll never want to let them go.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Wow.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I haven't had this much fun at the movies in a long, long time. From the music to the acting to the stunning art direction, Moulin Rouge is an experience.This is easily one of the best movies I've seen this year, and while I was watching it two things came to mind: 1) "I can't wait to see this again" and 2) "I can't wait for this to come out on DVD".If you get the chance, see it. You shan't be disappointed.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Impossible to resist!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Last night, I saw Moulin Rouge! for the second time since it began its theatrical run. My girlfriend and I were pretty much alone in an old, delapidated, small-town movie theatre--you could hear the speakers annoyingly hissing with age during the previews. Suffice it to say that I was not expecting my second viewing of the film to be as powerful as the first. I found that the opening bit of craziness at the Moulin Rouge (with Zigler screaming, etc..) was a bit grating. Yet, once Ewan and Nicole start singing to each other, the movie grabs ahold of you and doesn't let go. These people seem to be so in love, it's incredible. I can't wait for the DVD to come out so I can be won over again and again by these two actors' brilliant performances.</fullReview>

		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Seen it twice in a week and bought the soundtrack</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Never before have I enthused over ANY film as much as this one. I came to this site because I wanted to see if others enjoyed it as much as I did. I'm delighted to say that the majority of people feel the same way as me. I knew it was a Baz Luhrmann film, so I knew his approach would be different. So from the very beginning, he caught my attention.The film has everything, humour, wonderful singing, great songs produced entirely differently to how you've heard them before. Yes it's a simple love story, but what's wrong with that? It was delightful to sit back and just be entertained, without having to concentrate on following the plot. I've now been to see it a second time this week and have bought the soundtrack, which is getting played non stop. I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys musicals.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-10-24</date>
		<username>poem</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Highly overrated, but still good.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After such supermovies this year, like 'Shrek' and 'le fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain' (Amelie from Montmatre), claiming that this nice but decent movie is the years best one sounds simply absurd in my ears. I have to admit that this movie not even succeeded to be my favorite of the week !No question, the singing is okay, dialogue is good, and there are quite some nice jokes in it. But the movie does basically nothing but bathing the watcher in cliche, telling him or her such well hidden secrets such as 'there is nothing more important than love'. I really often felt quite bored by that.And the environment embarrassed me. The Moulin Rouge is actually nothing but a brothel in Paris ! A place where rich old men buy poor young girls. A prison. A shame for mankind. Whatever. But in the movie, it is treated with a glory as if it would be a kings palace !Too, many story parts couldn't raise my interest at all. The whole part with the jealously could, if at all, make me laugh. Whats the point there ? The man should have known that he is fallen into a whore ! What did he expect ? That she immediately transforms into an angel now ?In the end, 'Moulin Rouge' is nothing but a female counterpart to 'Fast and Furious'. Instead of action you get song and dance, and instead of coolness and freedom you get romance. But I liked the far more realistic characters from 'Fast and Furious' more than these boring stereotypes from 'Moulin Rouge'.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-10-24</date>
		<username>slerp</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The musical strikes back</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let's face it: Musical cinema sucks. Not counting Disney's animated musicals, you can count the good hollywood musicals of the last 30 years the fingers of one hand. Now Baz Luhrmann, king of camp, emperor of indulgence, gleefuly and effortlessly bucks the trend with a movie that's everything great about musicals. It's dazzling, hedonistic, spectacular and it lifts your soul up into the clouds.Set in bohemian Montmartre, around the turn of the last century, Moulin Rouge tells the story of a young writer (Ewan McGregor) who falls in love with a beautiful courtesan (Nicole Kidman) who seems way out of his league. It's a simple, tried and tested story. There's nothing challenging about this movie, and therein lies the secret of its success. The music is borrowed from 20th Century artists as diverse as the Beatles, Nirvana and Madonna and the plot is borrowed from a variety of sources such as "La Boheme" and "Midsummer Nights Dream". But throwing these elements into the mix with this degree of success is an achievement of sheer genius.Visually, Luhrmann pulls out all the stops and lets rip with a stunning display of effects. The result is breathtaking. This movie is up there with Jurassic Park and the Matrix in terms of redefining what technology can do for a movie. The scene in which we are introduced to the Moulin Rouge and it's proprietor is blinding. You feel you have to steady yourself for fear of falling out your seat and getting sucked into the screen.Of course, the danger of experimentation is that the results are often hit and miss. Fortunately there's 10 hits to every miss here. Highlights:The love medley that takes in David Bowie, Dolly Parton and the BeatlesThe dramatic highlight of the movie: RoxanneThe truly spectacular spectacular finale show9/10</fullReview>
	</review>

The whole story was good but the way the whole film was put together was amazing. Nicole and Ewan are great together, good chemistry, great acting talents and wonderful singing voices. a fantastic film once again from the great Baz Lurman. if you love drama, musicals and great films you'll not want to miss this! 10/10</fullReview>

Ewan McGregor was amazing as the sweet and innocent Christian (Just look at his eyes!!! They are so genuine!). Many people are complaining about the simplicity of the plot. Well, quite honestly I didn't even notice. I was too astounded by the beauty and wonder of the film. I thought the plot was good actually. So what if it's been done before? Romeo and Juliet had been done a million times and Baz still found a way to make it brilliant and original. He did the same with this film. I don't see how anyone could dislike it.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-10-22</date>
		<username>jrm-3</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fantastic and Magical</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For the first fifteen minutes of this movie, I was sure I had made a mistake. I was totally caught off guard, and the quick-cutting style of Luhrman made me dizzy and almost nauseous. But then, something magical happened. Nicole Kidman came on the screen, and the movie suddenly switched gears. It slowed down a bit (just a bit, but enough), and a love story began. Familiar songs, such as "Your Song" filled the theater. And suddenly, without warning, I fell in love with the movie. I couldn't believe the change from my initial reaction to my end reaction. I think some people absolutely hated this movie because they couldn't shake that initial reaction, whereas I sort of fell into the fantasy of the whole experience. Yes, it's silly that they're singing modern songs. Yes, it's silly that, at one point, they appear to float among the clouds while pixie dust sprinkles around them. But I accepted these as images, almost as metaphors, to help explain the excitement and beauty of the love story. To make a long story short, ignore the bad reviews and give the movie a chance--and stick around past the first 15 minutes--and you'll see that it's truly unforgettable.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<username>Dockelektro</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Spectacle with some under achievements</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I would really expect the most after "William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet". I would really expect the rebirth of the musical movie. But one thing doesn't let me score this movie higher than 7. I would also expect a better vision of Montmartre and Paris altogether. This movie lacks universe, because the action and the characters are too restricted. What I mean is that this musical lacks that epic vein it could have, because everything turns around that group of 5 or 6 people, that group of 4 or 5 buildings (the rest of the audience and the people are man with top hats and girls with dresses, let's face it) and the result is a grand musical film, but which is presented with the scenery range of a play (just count the scenes that don't take place on studio). And this is the thing that left me craving the most, since I think Luhrmann's nuts were really too big when he grabbed music from the 80's and put them in 1900. There are too many musical highlights, but if I could choose one that really touched me more than the others, it's gotta be the powerful "Tango de Roxanne", which is as achieved as any masterpiece song we ever heard, and works also as a summit to all the movie. This is my conclusion: the movie is great, could have been even better. Love those opening credits, though. And oh yeah, how on Earth did they managed to turn John Leguizamo into a midget? He looks real, there seems to be no digital manipulation or so!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-10-18</date>
		<username>ralphvz</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Truth, beauty, freedom, love</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I finally got around to see this film, I thought it would be a good film, boy, how wrong I was, it was a great film.It's a love story, but not only about love for another human being, but also for the love of art. Art in any sense, music, cinema, architecture, etc. Whichever form. All is being brought to us by the almost forgotten form of cinema, musical. The film-musical had it's prime during a time of depression and war, which main purpose was to give a little joy to the people. During the fifties and sixties, they tried to make them a little bit more serious or to take big Broadway productions to the screen. But by the summer of love the musical was as good as dead.So now we enter the 21st century and a whole generation doesn't know what movie-musicals are all about. They have never seen films with Gene Kelly - Judy Garland - Fred Astaire. What Baz Luhrman did was great, create a modern day version of "Singin' In The Rain", a film packed with modern classic songs. "Moulin Rouge" is the same concept as "Singin' In The Rain", old songs covered in a new story. The only distinction is that Baz Luhrman also gave the old songs a make-over. So we have a musical for the MTV-generation. It was a bold idea which happened to succeed perfectly.Nicole Kidman, Ewan McGregor and Jim Broadbent were wonderful. The art-direction, cinematography and costumes were spectacular and the choice of music terrific.In my eyes you can only hate this film, if you loath music or cinematography. But for me these forms of art are a basic human need, just like oxygen, food, water and love."Moulin Rouge" a lust for the eyes and ears. 10/10</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-10-14</date>
		<username>sibisi73</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>If you love excess...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>An incredible sensory overload, 'Moulin Rouge!' sees Baz Luhrmann almost lose control of his own fertile imagination. The whole movie is a complete WOW! I haven't seen anything so creative, both in style, and content, for a long time. Everything about this movie screams excess, and that's what you get. There is so much going on that at times it is just too much. The first 20 minutes or so is a cacophony that takes a while to acclimatise to...but once you do you should be wrapped up in the whole experience.This is first truly musical musical in a very long time, with astonishing inventiveness applied to the script, the choice of songs, and the cinematography. The mixture of contemporary pop songs and turn of the century showmanship is inspired. Everyone involved gives 110%, especially the two leads who bravely dive straight into each song and survive with their dignity intact. Jim Broadbent almost steals the film, but it is such a collective effort that it would be unfair to mention it! Everyone (including 20th Century Fox) seems to have taken a leap of faith in making this movie, and it seems to have paid off. The only nagging doubt is that, with so many fancy trimmings, the emotional heart of the story is suffocated.A must-see twice movie, because first time round you'll be reeling.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-10-14</date>
		<username>sdubos</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>energy driven by easy love, if not rythm...Alas!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Love, Love, Love...it seems to be the only purpose of this musical... True, the action and settings are really great; everything is in excess of everything: it is nervous, vibrating, loud (sometimes too loud). It's cacophonic in the first half hour, so that you lose almost all contact with the story, but you later get back on your feet. But when you consider the plot, it's really predictable. If a simple story is not really a problem for the first half of the film, with so many other things occupying your mind, it becomes a big one when the action is slowing down in the second part. Here you discover the one-sided face of the characters, the simplicity of the script at a whole : the total weakness of the second role characters (never seen such an insignificant Toulouse-Lautrec in a Montmartrian movie...), and the relatively small variety in settings starts to really suck towards the end. The movie is promising at the beginning, but end in a very loose way due to a total lack of rythm, if not love!!! Amelie is far more fun and captivating, if you want to deal with the "Paris-clichés" romances...without the boring. I give 4/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Peter Elefant</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Indeed a musical for people who don't like musicals.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What a spin! Moulin Rouge! is beyond anything ever before. A perfect mixture of love and musical, drama and dance, comedy and cabaret. It uses whatever it likes from modern music, and tosses away everything it doesn't like about musicals and theater. (Eat this Saturday Night Fever!)The images strike you first, with amazing zooms and spins and cuts, the story is highly paced and perfectly timed with the charming, funny and sometimes even heartwarming. (Wait a second. Gonna shed a little tear here)The plot is downright idioticly simple, but the mixture of different genres and funny twists, the anarchy and the daring, makes you forget that. Hell. The lovestory of this film is topped only by pieces such as "Edward Scissorhands" and "Bram Stoker's Dracula". And right now, even that seems debatable!The actors are all great, and they perfectly portray the image of good, evil, love, desire and most of all SHOWTIME!!!Baz Luhrmann has overdone himself this time, and it seems to me, that his career can ONLY be downhill from here.10/10 - shut up and go see the movie.</fullReview>

I usually like musicals and am tolerant of cheese in a movie, but this one is just pure special effects fluff. 		<date>2001-10-07</date>
		<username>valadas</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Again the story of Traviata</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Those who think that the era of the great musicals is over will see their opinion denied by this movie which combines the old musical tradition with a lot of digital special effects more adequate to the animation movies but which match with the general purpose of this movie anyway. The editing mainly in the first part shows an overwhelming speed of successive plans almost psychedelic playing successfully with images and sounds and showing spectacular choreographic scenes. In the second part that image rhythm slows down a bit more accordingly with the dramatic plot that develops itself around a Traviata love story of the tb ridden courtisan and the young poor but talented writer. Near the end there is a fabulous musical dance with an Argentinian theme which makes counterpoint with the dramatic scene where the courtisan is going to sacrifice herself to the lust of the rich Duke who is financially supporting the show. The weakest part of the movie is the soundtrack mostly made of more modern melodies like "The Sound of Music" which have nothing to do with the movie supposed era. Their inclusion results in an anachronism which we cannot understand. This movie could be better but is good enough anyway.</fullReview>
	</review>

It's that the movie shows the ending at the beginning. I was so disappointed. The ending was obvious in it because Christian (Ewan Macgregor) begins telling the story of Satine a smoldering temptress who is in love with him, but she finally dies because of a disease. It didn't make sense. Christian told us the story, but he first told us about Satine death. I mean it'd have been much better if he wouldn't have told us anything at the beginning. The movie lost interest after finding out that she was going to die. It was the worst thing about this movie. Anyway even though it failed on it. I think it was the best story about love ever told. The dancers and the music were amazing as well as the climate, we could see all the seasons like winter, summer, etc. I'll never forget when Satine told him that she didn't love him because she loved the duke instead.At last this is a great movie, but it shouldn't have told us the ending at the beginning. 	<review>
		<date>2001-10-07</date>
		<username>Allison Murphy</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Paradox: Cheesy but tasteful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was La Boheme - with a serious twist. I thought the parallelisms were sweet. I loved the tome and atmosphere of the movie. The stage came alive and you felt like you were there. And just as the Moulin Rouge played popular music of the day. So did this. The scenery took you back to a place you'd never been and the music was intended to make you feel as if this was your Moulin Rouge. As if then were now and vice versa. T.S. Eliot's "objective correlative" if you will. The problem is that I felt thrown off by the medley of popular love songs. It felt out of place, out of time and out of character to me instead of drawing me in - which I believe was it's intended purpose. Still I have a good deal of professional respect for the gutsy decision to take that chance. The movie itself is full of lively vibrant characters and the scenery and costumes are gaudy to the point of storybookish. Worth seeing, if only for the sake of interest.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-10-07</date>
		<username>riesjeroos</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Spectacular, spectacular!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm not too fond of musicals, I don't like soppy love stories with predictable endings and I am not a frequent visitor of posh brothels either. Still, I was simply dazzled by Moulin Rouge.The first fifteen minutes of the movie were very fast and flashy, almost music video-like. Some (middle aged) people right next to me in the cinema started shifting around their chairs uneasily, but I'm sure they got what they waited for after a short while anyway. I didn't mind the beginning at all, I thought it was a very clever way of portraying the chaotic and lively atmosphere in the famous nightclub.After the initial chaos died down a bit, the viewer got a tragic love story about the poor English writer Christian (McGregor) who falls in love with the posh dancer Satine (Kidman) in the famous Parisian nightclub Moulin Rouge. However, she has to be the lover of a very rich duke who pays for the production of Spectacular spectacular, the new Moulin Rouge show. This is a story about a poor sitar player who falls in love with a courtisane, but she has to marry the wealthy maharadja. The parallel is clear, I think. Satine and Christian start a secret affair, but the jealous duke gets suspicious and does anything to stop the passionate love affair between the two. The premiere of Spectacular spectacular is a tragic climax of the love story: will Satine choose for the duke's money, or follow her heart for the first time and leave Moulin Rouge together with Christian?It is not the story that makes Moulin Rouge such an interesting picture, it is in the incredible way it is told. Fabulous camera shots, interesting use of classic and modern pop songs (Madonna's Material girl and The Police's Roxanne will never be the same) and most of all, very good acting and singing of the two heroes, Kidman and McGregor. Never knew they could sing at all, so I was a bit sceptical about this aspect of the film beforehand. But I must admit I was quite impressed, particularly with McGregors efforts. Give 'em both and Oscar, and the person who cast Miss Minogue: give him two (for his guts).</fullReview>
	</review>

Moulin Rouge was imho the best love story I have ever had the privilege to watch. Many of them are typical, only the scenery changes. Here the scenery is blown to such shocking contents that you feel as if being in a theme park of some sort. And it's not a crappy theme park. After a movie, besides the "feel" of it I always try to analyze it's good and it's bad points. After Moulin Rouge I could not find any weak points. The directing was great (thx Buz :), the acting (I could not imagine a better line up, all the roles were great), the COSTUMES, the scenery, the drama! I hope you won't take me for a freak but I just came back from THE SHOW and I'm still hot over it.You will have many great moments while watching this movie, from mad laughter, through sadness, despair to contemplation. 		<username>Otis Lou Bohr</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderful One-Third of a Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I was first subjected to repeated viewings of the "Moulin Rouge" trailer (which preceded repeated viewings of "Memento"), I swore that I would only watch it if someone paid me, say, ten dollars to (above and beyond admission, transportation, and popcorn). It looked to be the worst of Romance and Musical distilled into one dire waste of celluloid.But then I started hearing good things. Enough good things that I eventually dragged myself down to the two-dollar theatre to see it(after having procrastinated for a week or two in the hope it would finish its run and save me the hassle).So, you know, I'm not expecting much. I'm fully prepared to walk out; heck, I didn't even buy popcorn. So I'm rather surprised to find that within the first minute I'm thinking, "you know this isn't half as bad as I'd thought it would be." And by the time twenty, thirty minutes have elapsed, I'm thinking my God this is GREAT, how could I almost have missed seeing this film, I am going to sing its praises from the rooftops, *force* the unenlightened to go see it (see "Memento", above).And then, apparently, the plot kicks in. The part most people seem to enjoy the most. The endless repetition of a few choice utterly banal lyrics set to an absolutely unmemorable tune. That's right: the worst of Romance and Musical distilled into one dire waste of two-thirds of a movie's worth of celluloid. What can I say, truth in advertising.Still, the first third was so great that it sticks in my mind almost a week later, makes me want to see it again. I'm contemplating forming a first-third-of-Moulin-Rouge fan club...</fullReview>

		<date>2001-10-04</date>
		<username>suzloua (dancing-round-my@handbag.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Oh my god - so good!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thought this film sounded okay when I first heard of it, and then I saw the trailer. I decided it sounded a bit heavy going, and so ignored it for the first week of release. Then I saw the trailer again when I went to see something else, and read a brilliant review of it, and so thought again. And I'm so glad I did!This film is incredible. Nicole sings like an angel, but it's Ewan who's the real surprise - if he made an album, it would probably be ridiculed, but he has a real talent. It's not fair, really - gorgeous, sexy as hell, amazing voice, brilliant actor, and knicker-meltingly sexy Scottish accent to boot! His wife is a bloody lucky woman!The film has wonderful sets, a fantastic cast, and the songs are brilliant. The original songs, eg. Come What May (a beautiful ballad between Satine and Christian) are spectacular, and the working of modern classics such as Your Song and Roxanne into the fibres of the film is cleverly and expertly done. SEMI SPOILER: At the end, you can't help crying when Satine dies (this is only a bit of a spoiler because Christian says in the first five minutes that she's dead), because the acting is so spectacular, it's like someone you know and love. SPOILER DONE. When it finished, everyone in the cinema sat still for about the first thirty seconds of the credits - something I've never seen happen before, and I go to the cinema on a pretty regular basis. Really, it was kind of funny - the cynical British public, brought to a complete standstill by a film.That is why if you haven't seen this film, YOU HAVE TO!!!!!!!!! Not to sound too mushy, but it really touches you inside, even moreso than Romeo + Juliet. Roll on Baz Luhrmann's fourth.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Incredible!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Um.. wow. When I first watched it on a big screen with larger than life sound, I was slightly turned off at parts. Maybe I couldn't take in all the information and process it in such a short time that the director allowed. Maybe I was trying to apply past experiences to this new one, and failing. By the end of the movie I was going over what I had just seen and I was stunned. Stunned by the skill of the director. How does one, or many for that matter, orchestrate such a magnificent scene, such as Christian's first night at the Moulin Rouge? Then how does one string hundreds of similar scenes together to form such a `Spectacular Spectacular' Movie?I keep going back to the first bedroom scene where Satine and Christian fall in love and think to myself. Oh my god, I really like that Elton John song. I must have replayed that scene a hundred times by now. For this scene alone it is worth buying this movie.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-09-22</date>
		<username>Hugh Everett</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A wildly energetic, fantastically filmed musical extravagance</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having had no idea what to expect, I was fascinated and stunned by this film. It's billed as a musical romance, I think, but that's like billing "Star Wars" as a space adventure - it just doesn't describe it.There will be some who don't like "Moulin Rouge!". Much like there were some who didn't rate "Toy Story", "Star Wars" and "Gone With the Wind" when they first came out. Go with an open mind and you will love this film.The only thing that didn't work for me was the story, because there was nothing new in it. But you don't go to this film for the story.Mere words can't capture the spectacle of "Moulin Rouge!". A picture paints a thousand words, but this picture needs 10,000 to give it adequate description. Suffice to say: expect wild music, amazing choreography, stunning camera work, superb costumes, incredible sets, wondeful post-production work ... and you'll still be over-awed by the complete effect.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-21</date>
		<username>Thomas Engels</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>New Opera for the New Century</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moulin Rouge! starts with a tell-tale scene of a conductor working himself in a sweat conducting an imaginary orchestra before large curtains.Expecting a pseudo-historical romantic view of turn-of-the-century Paris, I got thrown into a turbulent vaudeville. Instead of a voyeuristic approach the director had the guts to actually throw me smack in the middle of the actual stage without so much as a warning.At first I plucked my eyebrows but it was simply irresistible. Moulin Rouge! is loud, outrageous... and deeply moving.The heart of the movie is a classic opera-style tale filled with romance, deceit, treachery and death. The form however is far removed from anything I have ever seen. The musical accompaniment is a skillful medley right across twentieth century music. What to think of a room filled with men in cylinder hats dancing to "Smells Like Teen Spirit" by Nirvana?. If Verdi lived in our time, would this have been his approach? Who knows, and who cares. I could never get enough of this exuberant, rich and yet somehow sober performance.The acting is excellent, with outstanding roles by Nicole Kidman and Jim Broadbent. The director is both ubiquitous and subtly withdrawn. Ubiquitous in the loving care that went into every detail. Withdrawn in the strict adherence to the self-set rules of the story and the way it is told. Not once do you tell yourself: "Hey wait a minute, this is a movie! I am sitting in a theatre, and this isn't real!"The story is told in one long trait. At the intermission I actually felt like having had desert, and still had half the movie to go.To finish off the compliments, the movie, besides being a real tearjerker, is simply great fun. You can't miss the scenes where the rotund theatre director sings "Like a Virgin". And it works!Don't miss Moulin Rouge!</fullReview>
	</review>

I won´t forget the day I saw this movie. I don´t know if I´m in love with Satine or Nicole, I think with the two of them. I recommend this movie to all people who likes musicals, frenetic dance, deep stories, and above all, love. The greatest thing you´ll ever learn is just to love and be loved in return. 		<username>Ken Lau</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Simply Spectacular!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's been almost a week since I've seen this film, and I still cannot get over how stunning the experience was. No doubt, I will see it again this weekend, and it's funny to me that as much of a ride the film was, there are many parts that I do not remember. Perhaps that was part the joy, of being taken for such a wild rush that everything becomes a blur. From when the curtains lifted (people who have seen the film will know what I mean) to the very end, I was absolutely transfixed. The director here did a flawless job of transporting the audience to another time and place, that despite its surrealness and displacement of time and culture, felt very real. Ewan McGregor, Nicole Kidman and the entire cast was brilliant, but the real star here are the images that the director delivers to us. A seamless stich of computer animation and sound stages, Technicolor and grainy B&amp;W, the visual pyrotechnics need to be seen and experienced to be believed. Echoing a statement from another IMDB user, I would feel very sorry for you if you do not enjoy this film.</fullReview>

		<username>rdarlington (rdarlington@cwu.org)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Reinvention of the genre</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My deep love of the cinema embraces most genres, but the musical is probably my least favourite. Yet Australia director, co-producer, and co-writer Baz Luhrmann has virtually reinvented the genre with this visual extravaganza which has furious pacing, stunning sequences and startlingly fresh versions of recent songs as well as older ones. Nicole Kidman has never looked more striking than as the French courtesan Satine, while Ewan McGregor, the writer, and Richard Roxburgh, the Duke, are fine if theatrical as the two suitors with their rival offerings of love and riches respectively. This is a movie which it's hard not to like, such is its exuberance and charm.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Best since American Beauty and in some ways better</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>All good films have to be good on at least one level.Gladiator was an epic, American Beauty ironic, Priscilla Queen of the Desert kooky, Delicatessan original, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon beautiful, Kes sad, Chocolat romantic and Shrek plain funny.Moulin Rouge manages to be all of these at the same time(maybe not an epic!). The scenery and characterisations are enchanting, the notion of displacing music could have been disasterous, but worked out just fine. In fact, it was what Topsy Turvy should have been (Jim Broadbent please note).It won't be everyone's cup of tea, but after the nightmare of New York this week, Moulin Rouge was a terrific piece of escapism in the grand manner. 10 out of 10 without hesitation. Baz Luhrmann goes into my book with Sam Mendez and Stephen Poliakoff.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-09-13</date>
		<username>Watcher</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Almost Perfection!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My wife and I came out of the cinema stunned. This is cinema taken to the edge. Presenting the performance as if we were sitting in a live theatre. The colours are incredible, so bright and vivid. Excellent settings and costumes. The essence of the age was captured so well. OK, so the singing voices aren't perfect, but the way the songs were intertwined was witty and amusing. And for a thirty something like myself I amused myself trying to spot the various song titles throughout the film. I can also understand the negative criticism. If musicals aren't your cup of tea this film would be dire. Indeed I was reluctant to go and see it and this is the only failing: i.e. as it is a musical it will put people off. But if you open your eyes to this feast of a cinematic presentation then this film will be very hard indeed to better. Here's hoping Nicole Kidman gets an Oscar nomination, as well as various members of the production team from the director to designers. A brilliant piece not to be missed.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-13</date>
		<username>Stefano Casali</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>What cinema is all about!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A bleary evening in London was threatening at which point the idea of seeing Moulin Rouge was cast in my direction. Not having heard much of it, knowing about the famous night-spot in Paris and having seen a less than invigorating trailer left me a little unsure. I gave into peer pressure and we took our seats.From the very beginning of this movie I was hooked. It was the saline in my cinematic drip from minute one to minute 127. Left brain-dead by the usual Hollywood fare, this rocked me into consciousness and had me by the short and curlies all the way through.You can read elsewhere the details of the plot, so I'll refrain from a refrain, but if you are after an all-out cinematic assault in the way cinema was intended, then you need to see this movie. Not only is it a welcome break from the more moronic Hollywood releases of, well, most of the time, it is a genuine emotional rollercoaster and visual triumph. Mash that in with glorious pastiche, sharp wit, spellbinding set dressing, photography and choreography and you have a real treat.Don't be put off by the fact that it is a musical. It is a musical triumph. In fact everything worked so well that I was left floundering in my seat until the end of the credits, as was nearly everyone else in the cinema. Extraordinarily refreshing movie making.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Here we are now, entertain us...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moulin Rouge is a splendid, opulent, extravagant celebration of dance, music and above all things, love. It will be completely lost on anyone for whom ?dance' is a drunken stagger at a wedding reception, for whom ?music' is a sorry collection of dust-gathering Celine Dion CDs or whose idea of ?love' is putting up with somebody just because you are scared of being left on your own. If this adequately describes you, don't bother going to see the movie, you will not understand it, and therefore you will hate it. Unfortunate really, as Moulin Rouge is quite simply the most entertaining, different and interesting film of 2001.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>misohungry (moviearistocrat5000@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Indescribable.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MOULIN ROUGE (2001) Rating: 10/10The new diabolical movie is out! It's the movie everyone should rush to the cinema to see! Yes, Moulin Rouge! Wow, just see how enthusiastic a movie can make you? It'll make you tingle with excitement and flutter with joy? That is the kind of feeling you get when you're watching Moulin Rouge, a endlessly enjoyable piece of filmmaking from Baz Luhrmann, who bought us the similar Romeo + Juliet in 1996. Luhrmann has created with his script and his immaculate direction a near-perfect slice of grand cinema. Nicole Kidman's performance is stunning, its about time she got a role like this, and the actress hasn't been so good or so daring since To Die For. Ewan McGregor is also his best in ages, lighting up off-screen with his narration and sparkling when he's acting on-screen. The costumes are delicious, the makeup is eye-catching, the editing is fabulous and the cinematography is just beautiful. The singing and songs are extremely strong and add to the movie's many good points. Seeing these actors recite some extremely famous romantic songs is at times funny and at others heartbreaking. Moulin Rouge is breathtakingly romantic, visually stunning and brilliantly offbeat, it is my favourite movie of 2001 and one of the best musicals of all time.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-08</date>
		<username>Spleen</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Baz, it's okay if a shot lasts for more than half a second - really, it's okay</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's also okay if we hear more than sixteen uninterrupted consecutive bars of the one song.I don't want to give the impression that "Moulin Rouge" is a bad movie, or even that I didn't enjoy it. Of course I enjoyed it. It's impossible not to. But it's an entertaining trifle rather than ... I don't know, rather than whatever it was trying to be. Luhrmann's earlier "Strictly Ballroom" is probably more the thing "Moulin Rouge" was reaching towards. It has the same unbridled cinematic hedonism, but with more depth, more coherence, certainly more sincerity. We're told more than once that this is a story of "truth, beauty, freedom, and above all, love". But the film has little to say about freedom and nothing whatever to say about truth and beauty - those three were thrown in simply to make up the numbers. Besides, what does the slogan MEAN? When the Bohemians announce that "truth" is one of their ideals, are they saying that one ought to tell the truth, or discover the truth, or face the truth, or are they speaking aesthetics, and saying something about art being true to life? Your guess is as good as mine.As for the editing - did Luhrmann HAVE to disfigure his fine creative work so much? A lot of the art direction is fantastic, but we can only find out that it's fantastic by a process akin to forensic science. We never get an uninterrupted look at anything. And even WITHIN the rare uncut shots, there's the appearance too much frantic cut-and-paste. This is exactly what people feared would happen when editors started to use laptops rather than scissors. With many movies it doesn't matter, but in this case Luhrmann could have made something special, if he hadn't put it through a blender.Don't let me dissuade you from seeing it (as if I could). You're bound to have fun. You'll be introduced to a lovely fantasy world (albeit one that feels only just large enough to hold the story Luhrmann tells), and there's no denying that the cast strain every muscle, nor that Luhrmann is inventive - and what's more, ambitious. The film wouldn't be as good as it is were it not for his admirable desire to make a lavish masterpiece along the lines of, and worthy of being placed alongside, such films as "The Children of Paradise" and "The Red Shoes". But has he succeeded? Not even close.</fullReview>
	</review>

Ewan McGregor is absolutely fantastic as an innocent and overly sentimental lovesick puppy (who knew the guy could sing like that?!), and Nicole Kidman´s cold beauty mirrors that of the leading ladies of old Hollywood. The direction, costume design, cinematography and musical numbers are to die for... it´s wild, it´s crazy and at times absolutely hillarious (highlights? Think "Like a Virgin" sang by a fat old man with a riddiculous moustache or an Argentinian mixing tango by Mariano Mores with Sting´s Roxanne). I can´t promise you that you´ll like this film... there´s a good chance you´ll absolutely despise it. 		<date>2001-09-07</date>
		<username>heather-57</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>not for the artistically deprived!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is great art. It revived my faith in the medium of film and it revived my faith in humanity.I went into it not caring much for Nicole Kidman and expecting that the anachronistic use of modern pop songs would be a travesty. Boy, was I wrong, on both counts. Kidman was utterly fantastic (she has got to win an Oscar!) and the use of pop songs was delightful. Ewan McGregor? Well, I liked him OK before, but he captured my heart in this. He was beautiful and luminous. Everyone was. They let their lights shine. That's thanks to Baz Luhrmann. He helped them to open up and do the weird scary stuff, like singing (which was so moving that it brought me to tears many times). Yes, the script was negligible but look what they did with it! Compare, for instance, to "Phantom Menace", which was an exercise on how to degrade the talents of wonderful actors."Moulin Rouge" isn't a perfect film by any means -- there's a section in the middle that feels disconnected and choppy, and I wish there was more dancing shown -- but no great work of art is completely perfect.If this movie doesn't win a cartload of Oscars then there's no justice in the world. But even if it doesn't, I'll still treasure it. Like the best films of all time, it catapults you to a different universe and brings you back changed for the better.Another opinion: my husband, a musician who has played in so many musicals that he hates the genre (and almost never sees movies more than once), has seen it twice. He thinks it's the best movie musical ever made. We can't wait for the DVD to come out!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>kbenson-1</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Breathtaking</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ultra-romantic, operatic in the grandeur of its ambitions, gorgeous to look at, musically astounding, witty and exuberant, endlessly inventive, and loads of fun, Moulin Rouge floored me. I don't think I have enjoyed a movie as much since my childhood, meaning that it transported me out of this world into its own unique universe the way Saturday matinees (didn't matter what was playing) did when I was a child. (This is not to claim that Moulin Rouge is as great as, let's say, Grand Illusion; but there are different kinds of masterpieces.) Kidman and McEwan are both splendid and of course both are splendid to look at. The supporting cast is uniformly superb, John Leguizamo especially endearing as Toulouse Lautrec. Sets, costumes are a delight. The film's musical director and whoever did the orchestrations/arrangements should both win the Nobel Prize in Music (if there were such a prize); musically Moulin Rouge is an absolute tour-de-force. I certainly can understand why some people might hate this movie (those, for example, with no sense of romance or humor; or those who find opera or, say, musical theatre, inherently ridiculous). And I know it's a much over-used word . . . but Baz Luhrmann is clearly a genius.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>rkwong</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Rush out and see it while it's still on the big screen</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went into this movie with no more than the barest notions of who the two lead characters were, and the knowledge that this was a musical (or, more accurately, a re-working of the standard movie musical). Since I was afterwards grateful I'd seen it with no pre-conceived ideas, I won't go into detail, except to say that if you haven't viewed it yet, you ought to run out and catch it while it's still playing the big screens.This is a film to be experienced big. With its gorgeously-detailed sets, swooping cameras, wild colors, and soaring music, MR needs to be seen on the same scale that it's presented. Suspend your disbelief when you walk in the theater door, sit back, and take it in. You're stepping into a different world.But not so different that it keeps the heart of the film from ringing true. Kidman and McGregor are are both breathtaking, and they sold me on their characters...and, most important, on each other's characters.And bonus--in this day and age, a film set in a hedonistic nightclub with no gratuitous sex and no gratuitous violence? It's shocking. Absolutely shocking.</fullReview>

		<username>Jan Koengeter (JanKoengeter8@webtv.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I love it</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't understand why some people don't like this film. Everyone I know found it at least to be entertaining. I was "knocked out" by its humor, clever use of music and even using lyrics occasionally as spoken dialogue. It was visually stunning. It was well cast, and the performances were very impressive. To those who complain that Ewan MacGregor lent all the real emotion to the story, may I point out what should be obvious because it's inherent to the script...there is meant to be a big difference between the two characters...a wide-eyed, innocent, romantic poet should seem more emotional than a jaded, worldly courtesan. And it is written from Ewan's character's viewpoint. Nicole expressed her character's emotions very believably, and she was funny in the humorous moments. I hope she chooses comedies more often than she has so far in her career. And finally, for the "Like A Virgin" number alone, this film was fun!</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-27</date>
		<username>Francisco Huerta (fjhuerta@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A modern cinematic masterpiece</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Being a fan of silent cinema, it strikes me as odd that I liked so much this movie. Then again, there is a very good reason for this.During the silent cinema golden era, visionary directors such as Fritz Lang, F.W. Murnau and others created bizarre interpretations of our world. They effectively expanded our perceptions by incorporating cinematic tricks, such as slanted angles, futuristic sets, chiaroscuro shots, and others.Moulin Rouge should be grouped among these movie wonders.This is cinematic art at its very best. The cinematography is fast, furious, and concise. Gripping. It locks your attention to the movie like no other I remember watching...(From now on, the review is *Chock full of spoilers*). ... for example, the opening shot, which is a movie theater within a movie theater, projecting an old movie of an old Moulin Rouge, with a music director conducting an orchestra playing the 20th Century Fox fanfare. Marvelous. The ending shot, with the gun flying overhead the Moulin Rouge and crashing with the Eiffel Tower. The entire depiction of the Moulin Rouge is amazing. The genius of the main character singing "Your Song" to the prostitute. "Roxanne" by The Police as a tango. Sheer geniality.Oh, and in case you are wondering, yes, there is a plot. And the ending is simply beautiful.You cannot miss it. It is a shoo-in for a perfect ten. It gets a 9, though, because I don't know how it will stand the test of time.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Jefferey T. Ward (jefferey31@sigecom.net)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best Musical - EVER!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although I've been a professional and semi-professional musician for over twenty years and an avid movie fan for over thirty years, most musicals have always bored me. Except for Jesus Christ Superstar, I don't think I've ever seen any more than once. That is until today. Moulin Rouge grabbed a hold of me and would not let go! Only five or ten minutes into the movie I knew I was in for a real treat. By the time we had reached the half-way point, I knew that I already wanted to see it again. And again I did. Immediately following the conclusion of the movie, I ran to the lobby to purchase another ticket. While I had heard Nicole Kidman sing a few bars before, nothing prepared me for the real talent she has. Furthermore, to listen to Ewan McGregor sing was worth the price of admission alone. Not only does this movie make great use of modern music (some very modern and some recently modern) but it utilizes musical bits and pieces and storylines from other movies, plays, and even operas. You'll even find lyrics from songs you may know being sung to different melodies and to other familiar tunes as well. Watch closely, you may even see a few parodies of some other familiar characters, too. It seems the more you know about music, movies, and the theatre, the more fun you'll have with this wonderful gem. This one's the next in line for my video collection!</fullReview>

		<username>johnsteede</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Terrific but depressing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The way the film started off was very interesting, as it was like a play of some sort and was in an old style from the early 20th century. The first half of the film was amazing, "spectacular, spectacular!" even. The film was vibrant for the most part and has interesting combinations of music ("Because We Can" and "Lady Marmalade" at the same time) and the way the characters interact with each other is amazing. However, they give away a major plot point before the first five minutes were over. The whole story was told in flash back, which I personally don't like as one can tell what will occur in the story from how the character is in the beginning. The humor is interestingly different from the norm and is very unique. The musical numbers are primarily in the first hour or so and the vibrant way it is shot shows the emotions the characters were feeling. Then the film turns to a darker point and is very different form the beginning. While the ending seemed to perk up, all of a sudden it turned back to the sadder side. Overall, I still enjoyed the film but it is more of a romantic film then the comedy side shown. The musical aspect was new and very good and I would recommend most people to this film.</fullReview>
