		<username>cheeze71</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>the music stays with me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm the kind of person who can enjoy movie purely for its presentation, style, atmosphere... movies that arouse my emotions, regardless of the plot. Seeing Moulin Rouge is like entering a dream world. The setting &amp; the scenes in the first half an hour of the movies are like the subconscious mind. I think memory is like this, they're impressions more than facts. okok, back to the topic. I went to see the movie 'cause I'm a fan of Ewan McGregor &amp; I like musicals. It ends up I got more than I wanted. The songs are great. Without the characters singing, I think I couldn't have empathy w/ them (the storyline is quite weak). The songs help the plot to develop so that There's no need to lay hints for the characters to fall in love w/ eachother. Even one song is enough to show us their love. (Music is a world language) Also, Nichole Kidman acts well &amp; she makes me have empathy to her. (also I'm a female, I can put myself in her role better)Although I like McGregor more in his wilder roles (like in "Velvet Goldmine" &amp; "Transpotting"), I still enjoy seeing him as the sensitive writer. After seeing this movie, the music still stays w/ me.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-13</date>
		<username>spinningaround</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A Tragic, Visually Exciting Movie...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I must say, I went in expecting to have a fun, engergetic musical(ala Grease), but came away from this movie teary-eyed. The film draws you in from the very beginning with it's exciting, visually stunning atmosphere. Ewan McGregor can sing very nicely, thank you and Nicole Kidman has a charming voice(somewhat like Olivia Newton-John's). The movie alternates from High energy wackiness, to very high drama. Moulin Rouge uses music from everybody from The Beatles to Madonna("Like a Virgin" is used in a scene that has to be seen to believed...a real hoot!). My only complaint is that the charming Kylie Minogue was only used very briefly as the Green Fairy in a very memorable moment. See this film, bring some kleenex...but you'll smile, you'll cry and you will be entertained!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-13</date>
		<username>Anya Williams</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Love lifts this movie up where it belongs!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Wow, words alone can't begin to describe the stunning display that is the movie, Moulin Rouge. After seeing this movie for the fourth time the only thing I could say was, "When is the next showing?" This is one of those movies that become the treasured favorite in your memories. The movie dances and sings in the hearts of all true romantics.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-13</date>
		<username>cheeze71</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>the music stays with me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm the kind of person who can enjoy movie purely for its presentation, style, atmosphere... movies that arouse my emotions, regardless of the plot. Seeing Moulin Rouge is like entering a dream world. The setting &amp; the scenes in the first half an hour of the movies are like the subconscious mind. I think memory is like this, they're impressions more than facts. okok, back to the topic. I went to see the movie 'cause I'm a fan of Ewan McGregor &amp; I like musicals. It ends up I got more than I wanted. The songs are great. Without the characters singing, I think I couldn't have empathy w/ them (the storyline is quite weak). The songs help the plot to develop so that There's no need to lay hints for the characters to fall in love w/ eachother. Even one song is enough to show us their love. (Music is a world language) Also, Nichole Kidman acts well &amp; she makes me have empathy to her. (also I'm a female, I can put myself in her role better)Although I like McGregor more in his wilder roles (like in "Velvet Goldmine" &amp; "Transpotting"), I still enjoy seeing him as the sensitive writer. After seeing this movie, the music still stays w/ me.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-12</date>
		<username>saviorguard</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Moulin Rouge Review: Nothing Less Then Perfect!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Personally, I think this movie is by far the best I have ever seen. Besides the music being absolutely amazing, not to mention by a certainly praiseworthy group of music artists, the whole of this film is no less then `spectacular, spectacular!' The selection of wild, exotic colors blended with the explosive charisma of an all star cast is perfect for one truly entertaining viewing. The cinematography is sheer genius, with some of the best transitions I have every seen, accompanied by some smooth, dazzling special effects. The captivating story line, a purely emotional voyage of dramatic standards, provides a sensation of amplified feeling only captured in those moments of true love. All of this combined with the radiant use of turn of the century clothing, set to the beat of modern generation's musical influences. With a superior cast, this group of inspiring performers outdo themselves again and again throughout the film. Also, I have to mention that the cast vocals are totally stunning! Even the soundtrack does justice to the essence of this movie. I'm sure you'll never expect what is ahead if you haven't seen this flick yet!!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-12</date>
		<username>Dianne Condley</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A beautiful movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was one of the most beautiful movies I have ever seen. The excitement grabs you and you don't want the movie to end. Nicole Kidman was gorgeous and the singing and dancing was amazing. The movie has everything. Comedy, drama, romance, it's got it all. The story reminded me a lot of Shakespeare in Love, which also is a fantastic movie, in that the writer writes his play as the real life events take place. You must see this movie! It is especially funny when they sing and dance to Madonna's Like a Virgin. Hilarious!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-12</date>
		<username>perridog1</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Good for the old guys too</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Some comment has been made that the high ratings map to young people and there may be something to this. My 10 rating is for the pure entertainment value. I think I have seen all of the all time great movies. Moulin Rouge tops the list for entertainment value and that is worth something. It is a good job that my daughter has not seen this because it gives my brother and I a good excuse for a second viewing. And I am looking forward to that I can tell you. Score two 10s from the over 50s.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-12</date>
		<username>Gerard</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Gilbert &amp; Sullivan Meets MTV</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If Baz Luhrmann's "Romeo + Juliet" (1996) was Shakespeare for the MTV generation, "Moulin Rouge" is Gilbert &amp; Sullivan on ecstacy.Laurmann's over the top portrait of turn of the century Paris is an explosion of sound and color that leaves the audience dizzy, disoriented, and begging for more. Its so sad it's being seen by so small an audience. This is a big, bold, daring, tasty, entertainment extravaganza that blows the doors off the theater. It's everything a movie should be, and then some. Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor are surprisingly appealing in their doomed love affair, and Jim Broadbent's brilliant turn as Zidler is in itself, worth the price of admission. A send up of Madonna's "Like a Virgin", with the rotund and whiskered Zidler as the blushing maiden should go down as a classic in cinematic comedy. From the love triangle, to the play within a play; from the mustache twirling plots to the wild score and breathtaking choreography, Moulin Rouge stands in a class by itself. So inventive and so beautiful are the production design and cinematography that they could literally stand alone. Laurmann propels us through the mean streets of Paris at breakneck speed, treats us to a magical waltz on moonlit clouds, and even serves up a glittering green fairy and a chubby faced singing moon. He jams the screen with illusions to other films ranging from "American Beauty", "Titanic", "Singing in The Rain", and his own "Strictly Ballroom." One can only hope that this under-appreciated effort will one day be recognized for the masterpiece it is. Bravo Baz!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-12</date>
		<username>Charlotte (crodriguez@accesscomm.ca)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Thank you for creating something so spectacular.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Phenomenal. Thank you to Baz and the cast and crew for such a phenomenal creation. Ewan McGregor- you have just become my new favorite leading man. Baz- to you and your wife- please continue with these kinds of films- they truly are life changing pieces for us. And I am so happy to see a musical in the new milennium do so well. </fullReview>
	</review>

I think I'll be seeing this again and again and again.. Ewan was a bit of a surprise with his heartfelt performance of Elton's "Your Song" and Nicole shone with her previously unknown pipes. All in all, WOW!!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-11</date>
		<username>Eric Rose</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>The Emperor has no clothes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Never mind about polarising the reviewers (or at least the professional ones) - this movie polarised me. The production is spectacular and lavish, the set design is outstanding but stylistically I was left cold.It's not entirely Baz's fault. He's more of an addict than a pusher, even though I know it was him sliding the needle under my skin. I felt dirty and used, even as (or because) I enjoyed the spectacular. Was I being cynically exploited (as other reviewers have suggested) by someone that was simply out to sell a product, or was I being offered something that the purveyor believed was a valuable insight into the inner workings of society?I can cope - cringeworthy as it was at the time - with 'The hills are alive with the sound of music'. I have more trouble with the love scenes. It appears that both Christian and Satine are incapable of expressing their emotions except through the regurgitation of lyrics from popular music. I find it hard to empathise with characters who pledge their undying love for on another by using phrases equivalent to 'In the words of Dolly Parton, "I will always love you"'. To be sure, musicals are based around scenes where emotions are expressed in songs, but they also have love scenes where the characters talk to each other rather than quote each other song lines.I am not immune to having had a song stuck in my head, or to associating songs with emotions and relationships. However, I do not confuse the song for the feelings. If being a romantic is shorthand for ringing up radio stations to get them to play 'our song', I'd have to say that I'm not a romantic. To me, being romantic involves a lot more - and at the very least it means refusing to express emotions at second-hand, which I see as a form of dishonesty.Baz's characters are emotional vampires, with no emotion but what they can suck from the carcass of popular culture. Maybe that was done deliberately. Maybe Baz meant this film as a satire on our obsession with living life vicariously. Certainly the overall effect was of a caricature, something larger than life - a fairy tale romance - which our post-modern sensibilities will judge as no more than pleasing fiction. The problem is that everyone has to be in on the joke for this to work properly.I feel that the film faultlessly panders to the lowest common denominator, where love becomes its own caricature and is debased in the process. Technically the film is a work of art, but it ends up feeling like a rock video clip - all style and no substance. I liked this film but hated doing so. Maybe the style was a cynical attempt to manipulate the audience. Maybe Baz believes that there is nothing new to be said artistically and that all new art can be no more that pastiches of existing works. In any case, I was left in awe of the technical achievements but untouched emotionally.I'm giving this a score of 6/10. That said, I think that it's a great film - possibly a classic, and it makes me wonder why I've given better scores to worse films. See it and marvel. Just don't leave your brains at the theatre door.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-11</date>
		<username>lowd</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Impression</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If Shakespeare could write a new play today, and Cezanne could design the set you might end up with something like "Moulin Rouge". This is a sweet little nightmarish dream sequence from beginning to end. The music, interwoven throughout without noticeable effort to chisel it into the plot, was beautifully done. I was moved to tears by the performances (and this time it wasn't because the acting was terrible). I loved this movie. It was purely flawless.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-11</date>
		<username>witkokodanwin</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Perfect Eye Candy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moulin Rouge was as wonderful a piece of eye candy as I've ever seen. The music was incredibly inventive, creative, and playful, and the visuals were as addictive as the "Green Fairy" that the characters regularly imbibed. Baz Lurhmann has scored another hit with the third installment of his "Red Curtain Trilogy". His flare for theater and dramatics really transfers quite beautifully to this film production. An impressive achievement! I've recommended this film to everyone that I know, and all who have seen it have loved it.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-11</date>
		<username>oceanjewel (lperkins@borland.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Opulent and toe tappin'!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I loved this movie. It was visually stunning - well worth seeing on the big screen or you'll miss some of the loveliness and glitter. It made me want to dance in my seat. Interesting renderings of some very familiar popular tunes. Ewan McGregor was adorable in this film. Nicole Kidman was beautiful as always. If you like dancing and singing and eye candy, you'll love this.One caution: if you don't like those old Hollywood musicals where the plot is just basically an excuse for a lot of singing and dancing to occur, and wouldn't like them with updated music, either, then don't see it. I happen to love those movies and wish they were made more often these days. I'd compare it to "Hair" or "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" for being a fun musical with modern music.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-11</date>
		<username>jessestlr</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Extremely brilliant</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Just when I thought Baz Luhrman couldn't make another movie as great as Romeo and Juliet, he makes Moulin Rouge. Moulin Rouge is easily so far this years best film and movie soundtrack. The music is what makes this movie. You'll laugh during the Like A Virgin number, cry when Kidman sings One Day I'll Fly Away. All in all, this is an extremely brilliant film. I would say this is the best musical of all time. Not only, musically is it a great movie, but the acting is superb. Kidman and Broadbent are brilliant, McGregor gives an honest performance, Roxburgh is scary, and Leguizamo was decent. Kidman and McGregor also have great singing voices. The rest of the cast have decent voices, (except Roxburgh, but he doesn't sing much.) This should get nominations at the Oscars for best song (a couple of them), makeup, costume, art direction, sound, score, editing, cinematography, original screenplay, supporting actor (Broabent), actress (Kidman), director, and picture( Which I hope it wins)</fullReview>
	</review>

Certainly the overall effect was of a caricature, something larger than life - a fairy tale romance - which our post-modern sensibilities will judge as no more than pleasing fiction. The problem is that everyone has to be in on the joke for this to work properly.I feel that the film faultlessly panders to the lowest common denominator, where love becomes its own caricature and is debased in the process. Technically the film is a work of art, but it ends up feeling like a rock video clip - all style and no substance. I liked this film but hated doing so. Maybe the style was a cynical attempt to manipulate the audience. Maybe Baz believes that there is nothing new to be said artistically and that all new art can be no more that pastiches of existing works. In any case, I was left in awe of the technical achievements but untouched emotionally.I'm giving this a score of 6/10. That said, I think that it's a great film - possibly a classic, and it makes me wonder why I've given better scores to worse films. See it and marvel. Just don't leave your brains at the theatre door.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-11</date>
		<username>lowd</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Impression</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If Shakespeare could write a new play today, and Cezanne could design the set you might end up with something like "Moulin Rouge". This is a sweet little nightmarish dream sequence from beginning to end. The music, interwoven throughout without noticeable effort to chisel it into the plot, was beautifully done. I was moved to tears by the performances (and this time it wasn't because the acting was terrible). I loved this movie. It was purely flawless.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>Elisabeth (holerocker@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Moulin Rouge is excellent!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Satinne is an aspiring actress who is stuck performing for Moulin Rouge until she is discovered. One night a Duke is in attendance at Moulin Rouge who will give Satinne her big break. Christian, the writer who wants to be discovered, is also and is mistaken for the Duke. Christian and Satinne meet and sparks fly, literally, while the real Duke is jealous. The visuals are amazing in this movie and the songs will keep you humming and kicking your feet. Go see it! I was very unsure about seeing this movie, but reluctantly went to see it with friends. I had no idea what it would be about. Within five minutes I was loving it. It is a whole new musical about love. The songs were great, and I loved the use of many titles in the Elephant Love Medley. The fact that Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor actually do their own singing really impressed me. I particularly enjoyed the "Truth Beauty Freedom Love" theme....Get the soundtrack! And I don't mean for Lady Marmalade......</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>Melody Jackson (mfilmakrj@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best film I've seen in a long time!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Moulin Rouge" is a classic story of love overcoming social and political obstacles, but is told with a very different twist. A period setting with modern music hightening every scene. The funny thing about it is....it works! Whoever arranged all the music deserves an Oscar, and even though we're only halfway through the year, expect "Moulin Rouge" to get a few Oscar nods in Costume Design and make up. The cinematography is like a theme park ride taking you through the streets of Paris and into the characters windows, and with more close ups the actors to really make you feel like your sitting right next to them. If you haven't seen this film yet, what are you waiting for? I've seen it three times and each time the audience applauds, which is something I haven't seen in a long time! So go, and don't take it too seriously. The film is a very entertaining ride through the wild nightlife of 20th century Paris.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>can can and modern music set in 1900 France... AWESOME!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>this was a really good movie. i had heard mixed reviews from my friends and decided i must see it for myself and make my own conclusions... my conclusion? it was "spectacular spectacular" to take a line from the movie.the beginning was hectic and frantic and exciting, and throughout the whole movie, there wasn't a single moment when i wasn't avidly watching the screen to see what was happening or the actors' expressions. the costumes were superb, the setting excellent... i very much recommend it. i loved the way they used modern songs. when i heard nirvana's "smells like teen spirit" i was in shock. when two of the characters starting doing a rendition of madonna's "like a virgin" i cracked up... i couldn't help it! and i loved the way one of the characters sang sting's "roxanne." it was a great movie musical, with lots of comedy AND romance AND drama... in general, it was "a story about beauty, freedom, truth, but above all, love." i'm definitely buying this when it comes out on VHS/DVD.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>Clarke-6</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Your senses are about to explode...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Without question this is probably one of, if not the most visually stunning pieces of cinamatic art ever. If this movie doesn't move you in some way, you must already be dead (I would suggest you find the nearest morturary and crawl into a casket). Besides the spectacular (spectacular) visual effects, the soundtrack, which virtually tells the whole story, will vault your sense of sound appreciation to levels you didn't know existed. Add to all this, the lavish dance/perfomance scenes and you have a prescription for OSCAR, OSCAR and MORE OSCARS! I realize it's a long time to the next "Oscar Awards" (and I don't care what movies come between now and then), but if the "Acadamy" and its membership doesn't find "Moulin Rouge" (2001) multiple Oscar worthy, then they need to go find "that morturary". Do yourself a favor, go see this movie. Just be sure to see it in a movie theater that has the latest sound system such as "THX", and be sure to ask whoever's in charge that you would appreciate it if they know where "10" is on the sound adjustment knob. ENJOY!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>DarkLadyLilith</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Truth, Love, Beauty all exist in this film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A love story in musical form, an operatic tragedy, a biting comedy, a riot and whirlwind of color and emotion, an eclectic mix of the old and new, and you only have to pay $5 to see it. Nicole Kidman stars as the stunningly beautiful Diamond of the Moulin Rouge, cybical and money grubbing with a Dark secret. Enter Ewan MacGregor, a penniless writer with "big talent"... An Evil Duke and the connsummate showman, Harold Zigler have their own parts to play and either bring the lovers together or keep them apart... If anything else, SEE THIS MOVIE. Words cannot suffice to describe the emotional toes you will have to this film.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>Joey (pyurevil@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Your eyes and ears will not be disappointed</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I highly recommend Moulin Rouge! Baz Luhrman of Strictly Ballroom, Romeo &amp; Juliet fame has reinvented the musical for the MTV generation. Moulin Rouge rocks! Literally! Aside from a couple of slow spots the film is a visual feast for the eyes. The colors, choreography, cinematography, costume design, set design, direction, and editing all combine to make it one wild ride. I must also mention the treat for the ears. Kidman and McGregor prove not only their acting merits but their vocal abilities! McGregor throws himself into his character and sings his heart out. The excitement and joy in his expression just make you want to believe! There was one musical number that I was not expecting and I was completely overjoyed. Judging from the audience reaction in the packed theater the crowd totally whooped that scene up! You'll know which one I'm talking about when you see it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>Lou48 (kiwi_48@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Wow</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I came with the expectation that this movie would be slightly strange, seeing as the director was the same as the one for Romeo and Juliet. I was not particularly impressed with the filming in Romeo and Juliet, but I admired the rest of the film. Moulin Rouge went way beyond my expectations for a movie. I had no idea the movie was about love, as the trailer had been slightly confusing and vague. What I discovered at the theater was a true gem. The movie very unassumingly takes its place within the category of musical, though the music in no way draws from the plot or the acting, but merely draws you into the story. Most musicals seem ridiculous in the way characters spontaneously break into a song or dance. This movie was in no way ridiculous. On top of that, the songs were familiar. In A Knight's Tale, a use of modern music was attempted, but to some haphazardous effect. In Moulin Rouge, the familiar music was wonderful because it was performed in an entirely new light. For example, I am not at all a fan of Elton John's "Your Song," but Ewan McGregor performed it so beautifully and with such feeling that I could not help falling in love with it. The acting was very impressive and believable, though Kidman was a bit over-the-top, but true to character. On the whole, this movie had a beautiful message to contribute and was expertly and entertaininly conveyed. A delight to watch</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>Nathan B. Tayor (gandalf-89)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A moderate improvement over Luhrmann's Romeo + Juliet</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wasn't expecting much of Moulin Rouge when I first walked into the theatre, having been dragged across town to the theatre by some friends. I simply despised Baz Luhrmann's previous film, the modern adaptation of Romeo + Juliet; I found that he simply took too many liberties with the script and tried a bit too hard to appeal to my generation. So, one can imagine my surprise when a friend of mine called 35 minutes before a showing of Moulin Rouge was to start to announce that he was picking me up to go see it. Well, $10.00 (damned Canadian ticket prices) and two hours later, I was suitably impressed with it.Not surprisingly, the visuals in Moulin Rouge are outstanding. The art direction seems to be far more sophisticated than in R&amp;J, and it really adds to the mesmerizing effect that the film has. The choreography is also outstanding. Surprisingly, the modern songs used in the musical numbers really worked in a queer way - After Jim Broadbent's "Like a Virgin" number, easily the best in my opinion, the audience spontaneously erupted in a frenzy of applause. However, the best thing about Moulin Rouge is the script. Which sucked. Really sucked. How, you ask, it is the script the best part of this movie? Simply put, because the script was so trite, so predictable, so blatantly "heartbreaking", one doesn't need to focus on it; rather, we're all so swept up in the quick cutting and fast-passed visuals that we really don't care about it. Furthermore, Moulin Rouge solves one of the issues that I had about R&amp;J - because I don't care about Moulin Rouge's script, there's no need for me to complain about it. I don't care what Luhrmann did to the script because it doesn't matter to me. All in all, Moulin Rouge was one of the better movies that I've seen in awhile. Don't expect any Oscar performances (though Ewan McGregor had a stunning singing voice- much to my surprise) or writing, but if you liked the visual appeal of Luhrmann's R&amp;J and Strictly Ballroom, give this one a shot.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-10</date>
		<username>Nathan B. Tayor (gandalf-89)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A moderate improvement over Luhrmann's Romeo + Juliet</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wasn't expecting much of Moulin Rouge when I first walked into the theatre, having been dragged across town to the theatre by some friends. I simply despised Baz Luhrmann's previous film, the modern adaptation of Romeo + Juliet; I found that he simply took too many liberties with the script and tried a bit too hard to appeal to my generation. So, one can imagine my surprise when a friend of mine called 35 minutes before a showing of Moulin Rouge was to start to announce that he was picking me up to go see it. Well, $10.00 (damned Canadian ticket prices) and two hours later, I was suitably impressed with it.Not surprisingly, the visuals in Moulin Rouge are outstanding. The art direction seems to be far more sophisticated than in R&amp;J, and it really adds to the mesmerizing effect that the film has. The choreography is also outstanding. Surprisingly, the modern songs used in the musical numbers really worked in a queer way - After Jim Broadbent's "Like a Virgin" number, easily the best in my opinion, the audience spontaneously erupted in a frenzy of applause. However, the best thing about Moulin Rouge is the script. Which sucked. Really sucked. How, you ask, it is the script the best part of this movie? Simply put, because the script was so trite, so predictable, so blatantly "heartbreaking", one doesn't need to focus on it; rather, we're all so swept up in the quick cutting and fast-passed visuals that we really don't care about it. Furthermore, Moulin Rouge solves one of the issues that I had about R&amp;J - because I don't care about Moulin Rouge's script, there's no need for me to complain about it. I don't care what Luhrmann did to the script because it doesn't matter to me. All in all, Moulin Rouge was one of the better movies that I've seen in awhile. Don't expect any Oscar performances (though Ewan McGregor had a stunning singing voice- much to my surprise) or writing, but if you liked the visual appeal of Luhrmann's R&amp;J and Strictly Ballroom, give this one a shot.</fullReview>
	</review>

Furthermore, Moulin Rouge solves one of the issues that I had about R&amp;J - because I don't care about Moulin Rouge's script, there's no need for me to complain about it. I don't care what Luhrmann did to the script because it doesn't matter to me. All in all, Moulin Rouge was one of the better movies that I've seen in awhile. Don't expect any Oscar performances (though Ewan McGregor had a stunning singing voice- much to my surprise) or writing, but if you liked the visual appeal of Luhrmann's R&amp;J and Strictly Ballroom, give this one a shot.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-09</date>
		<username>RALKSA</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A kaleidoscope of colour, movement and drama.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't like musicals but I loved Moulin Rouge. How many movies do you walk out at the end wishing to see again? This is definitely one to see again (and again).Baz Luhrmann has created a film work of art that sets a new standard for others to strive for. It's not possible to take it all in in one sitting. Like a perfect feast! Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor are outstanding in their leading roles and Nicole has the beauty of a translucent pearl (Tom who?).See Moulin Rouge and weep for any love you ever had and lost.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-09</date>
		<username>Karen (hollywood_scarlett@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Welcome to the Moulin Rouge!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Going to see to Moulin Rouge on it's opening night was a night i will remember. Baz Luhrman should be praise for his baby. People may have thought a movie musical was a sure firer flop. Also critics began to doubt it when it was delayed so many times and had to move to different places to be flimed.The acting was excellent. I was a huge ewan mcgregor fan before the movie came out so i always knew he could sing but, Nicole Kidman? She blew me away! I think that the song "Some Day I'll Fly Away" was one of the most touching parts of that movie. And Jim Broadbent! Bravo Bravo! he was amazing! And Like a Vrigin! HAHA!I smell some oscars indeed. Best Actor for Ewan McGregor, Best Actress for Nicole Kidman, Best Supporting actor for Jim Broadbent, Best Set Design, Best Costumes, Best Song for "Come What May" and of course best movie and director.I predict they will all be nomanited but, i'll like to see the movie that can top it!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-09</date>
		<username>Ryan Leroux (Ryan82)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Moulin Rouge is "Spectacular, Spectacular!"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Anyone with an ounce of common sense, can see that Moulin Rouge is a fantastic movie. Of everyone I have talked to most have said that it is a bad movie, but of everyone I've talked to that has actually seen the movie has agreed that it is a superb collection of music, acting and style. The others have made their opinions based on the trailers shown to the public, and that is the only problem with this movie, the poor (and lack thereof) advertising.Some people complain that movie trailers show too much about the movie and end up ruining it for the viewer. If this was what the Public Relations people from 20th Century Fox were trying to accomplish, then they have gone just too far. First of all, the trailer does not even make it evident that this movie is a musical. Secondly, there is no real clear indication of the plot. The only thing that is clear is that it is held in the early 1900's by the costumes and scenery in the trailer. This movie would have made much more money if the advertising was done better, and the only thing that can help bring in more money is the word of mouth of people who have seen the movie.The plot may be a typical love story, but the movie itself is far from typical. Baz Luhrmann, is not only a director, but an artist. His modern visions give the movie a uniqueness that makes it stand out and will make the viewer want to see it over and over again. A big round of applause has to be given to Baz Luhrmann and Marius DeVries for their work on the greatest soundtrack I've heard in a long time. The soundtrack is so good, that after seeing the movie I had bought the soundtrack the very next day when the stores opened, in fact I am listening to it now as I write this review. People should not just see this movie because it is a good movie, but because it is so unique and different than most people are used to seeing. Very few directors and their movies ever break out of the molds that seem to constrain the rest. Baz Luhrmann has already proved that he is able with his rendition of Romeo and Juliet and Moulin Rouge is no different. Overall, and in every small aspect, this movie is "Spectacular, Spectacular!"</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-09</date>
		<username>(mdukas)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Horrible yet Visually Wonderful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The good parts: fantastic visual creativity, Baz Luhrman and his wife (the production designer) went all out to create a no holds barred visual experience, very creative, no expense spared. Its clever that the main characters all have red hair (Nicole Kidman, Jim Broadbent and the Duke) and the "Redness" of the entire production is weird and wonderful. The red blood coughed up by the dying actress (But the dark complexioned writer, Ewan McGregor, stays in the "White Hotel". The weird use of lyrics from old Elton John songs, and other 70's and 80's hits, redone as operatic spectaculars, is creative, but very strained after 5 minutes. Then there is the Australian connection, it was filmed in Australia, Nicole is Australian, it was made by Fox, owned by Australian Rupert Murdoch, and something tells me Baz Lurhman must be an Aussie.The bad parts: cynical use of the same plot from Romeo and Juliet (already done by Baz) and "Titanic", you know beautiful young lovers, evil capitalist with gun-toting henchman ready to "whack" the beautiful boy. How about the "American Beauty" shot of the dying actress in the rose petals? The music is lip-synched, badly. The principals don't even appear to be trying to look like they are singing in some numbers, the actors and the songs are poorly synchronized, they just ran out of time and money evidently.This is a train wreck of a movie, but fascinating in the way that train wrecks are fascinating. It has some sort of family connection to Baron Munchausen and Topsy Turvy. Its hard for me to understand that Baz didn't somehow have something to do with those movies, since the look is so similar. This director is probably very good at making 2 minute music videos, visually arresting, with lip synched lyrics, but will the public accept MTV-the two hour movie? Time will tell.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-09</date>
		<username>makemeabird</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>WOW!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is so great! The music, dancing, story-keeps you glued to the screen. This is the first Nicole Kidman movie that didn't make me sick. Now I completely love her and can't wait to see what's next. Ewan McGregor should really have his own record contract! I would recommend this movie to anyone. Everyone needs to see it! A great modern-day musical!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-09</date>
		<username>Ginny Lewis (ginnylewis@excite.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>GO SEE THIS MOVIE. NOW!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm serious. Get over all the crap floating around about how it's cut too fast, it's too colorful, it's got too much music, it's trying to revive an out-dated movie form. Flooey. Sure, there's great camera tricks; unbelieveable production. Overkill, overkill, overkill on all your senses. But that's only to make the solid core - the real story - smack you all the harder when it's ready. God bless Baz, he understands love, and loss, and being human. Go see this movie. Go see it again. Buy the dvd. Consider yourself blessed.</fullReview>
	</review>

I did a lot of laughing, crying, and enjoying the film. The cast was amazing, and you begin to feel like you are part of the Moulin Rouge. The use of vibrant color and exciting music prepares you for an extremely entertaining 2 hours that you will talk about for weeks. I loved this film.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-08</date>
		<username>Sean (timmi002)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Spectacular Spectacular</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After I saw this movie, I could think of only 2 words to describe it - CLEVER and BRILLIANT. Nicole Kidman and Ewan MacGregor are amazing in the lead roles. Jim Broadbent and John Leguizamo are excellent in their very funny supporting roles as well. They can all sing, they can dance and they show such passion and emotion throughout. The music is incredible! I never buy soundtracks to films, but after seeing this film, I just had to have it. I have seen it twice now and would recommend this film to anyone who likes music, dancing, romance, comedy and quirky Being John Malkovich type humor. You never know Baz Luhrman is going to do next. Being inside his mind would be the wildest ride. The film is visually stunning from the Elephant to his take on 1900 Paris. If you like "different" and "extraordinary" then this is the movie for you.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-08</date>
		<username>danozdirect</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>finally...a movie with something special</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't think there's any way I could talk about this movie without gushing to tell you the truth but it was definitely worth my ten bucks to say the least. While I don't think its for everyone this was by far the most fun I've had in a long time. If you're sick of cheesy Hollywood movies take a look at Moulin Rouge. It doesn't try to pretend that its reality but rather takes the art of storytelling to a whole new level, leaving you breathless as the credits roll.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-08</date>
		<username>Jay Millington</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually stunning, magnificently crafted musical genius!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As much as I loved this movie, it is a difficult one to decribe in words. Ewam McGregor takes great songs and makes them greater, when you expect little but for them to be butchered. The speed changes in the film give it almost a roller coaster feel, propelling you through what you are not sure is a musical, or a spoof on musicals. This is honestly a movie I was dragged to by my fiancee, and I didn't expect to even stay awake through it, much less enjoy it, but I found myself going back to see it again two days later.One of the most captivating films I have ever seen. Thanks Baz.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-08</date>
		<username>lordirving</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fantastic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was like a wild rollercoaster ride in the beginning with a fast pace and striking camera angles. The music is beautifully arranged and can Ewan sing!!!! I saw it on Monday and was back again on Thursday and loved it just as much the second time. Even with a sad ending, I left the theatre energized. Simply wonderful.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-08</date>
		<username>TimeTrvlr03</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brilliant! Delicious buffet for the senses!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Baz Luhrmann manages, with Moulin Rouge, to take the fast pacing of Romeo + Juliet (which I did not like) and apply it effectively to this extravagant, musical love story. Kidman and McGregor are the perfect pair. His devastating good looks and her timeless beauty fit the scene perfectly. The wild nights of the Moulin Rouge, the famous French nightclub that provides the dramatic backdrop for this tragic tale, third in the "Red Curtain Trilogy" from Luhrmann. Satine (Kidman) is the tragic heroine, "Sparkling Diamond" of the Moulin Rouge. Christian (McGregor) is the Bohemian writer who becomes Satine's truest love and champion. Her beauty drives the Duke to bitter jealousy, which threatens the two lovers. The trailers may make you feel as if you know the end of the movie, but trust me, you don't!The plot is not complex at all. Its the simple tale of tragic, but pure, love. Satine and Christian represent all that is good, wonderful and right in love and the world; their story shows that love can overcome everything, except nature. The Duke is the evil that can destroy such beauty. All of the relevant details play out in the sumptuous sets of the film. Lavish replicas of the once great club, right down to the elephant, historically acquired for the Moulin Rouge at the World's Fair. The costuming is gorgeous, vivid colors and rich fabrics. Further, there is a wonderfully comical and supportive cast of characters (Zidler, the Unconscious Argentinian, Toulouse Lautrec, etc).And boy can Kidman and McGregor sing!!!! They are outstanding in their duets and can even carry themselves on their own. They don't hide behind backup singers and studio recordings, they just belt the songs out for our enjoyment. The other songs in the film are wonderful, new renditions of old favorites (Like a Virgin, Lady Marmalade, Up Where We Belong, etc). They are relevant and fast paced, in keeping with the movie. (I must note that there was one musical element that my sister absolutely hated -- the singing moon. It was a bit much. :-))This movie is a masterpiece and I will be buying it the moment it comes out on video.My rating for this movie would be off the scale!! Enjoy!!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-08</date>
		<username>scoobysnax4695</username>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-07</date>
		<username>Corro</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Totally moving. A fabulous blend of music, song, cast, and story.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I consider myself enough of a fan of mainstream cinema to know what makes a good movie.This is it.Baz Luhrmann and the cast and crew have combined to provide the ultimate musical presentation - you feel like you are actually watching a stage show as part of a theatre audience. The story and its telling are superb (if not new). From the first appearance of the curtain you become gripped by the emotions of the characters AND your own recollections of the various songs included in the magnificent soundtrack.I felt a wave of blissful goosebumps at several points as I was so moved by the performances of Nicole and Ewan (and Jacek Koman as well).Moulin Rouge is a reminder of the power of cinema.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-07</date>
		<username>tncook</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Beautiful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie was beautiful. The whole light/dark and use of colors was awesome. I love Lurhmann's work (ie Romeo and Juilet). The acting was nothing special, but then its hard to develop a character that we are used to when they randomly break out into a song.The story was mostly predictable, but it fit the "storybook musical" feel. You pretty much know what is going to happen, but the fun part was actually seeing it happen. Its a feast for the eyes. The music on the other hand was weird. The modern score was cool at times, but sometimes it seemed out of place, and way too stupid (like when he keeps saying "love lift us up where we belong, all we need is love". But there is something funny about a grizzled deep throated Argentinean singing Roxanne. I think that a few of the songs were original, the one that he sings when he meets Satine, and the "secret love song to remind them of their love"The choreography was nothing short of fabulous, it was in the sense of a full blown musical. The costumes... They were period, but with that feel that you could almost wear some of it out on the street today. I think that this is a movie that will set some trends, especially for women. I think that we will see a lot of that stunning red lipstick. But also things like corsets and fishnets. Everything in Satine' s wardrobe is amazing. She never looks less then glamorous, even when all she is wearing is a sheet and there is just something about Nichole Kidman in merrywidow and thigh-highs.I liked the movie for the style that it was done in. Everyone i went with complained about how it was badly acted and the plot lacked (although the movie was a remake of a 1952 version http://us.imdb.com/Title?0044926). I think that this movie could be watched over and over just because it is so beautiful. There is always something that your eyes draw to. I'll buy the DVD.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-07</date>

		<shortDescription>Finally! A break from Hollywood's monotony!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went into the theater with my girlfriend reluctantly to see Moulin Rouge. But this movie, for lack of a better term, rocked my world. I was not expecting the jolt I got in there. I am so glad to see a director and a film turn a cheek to the critics and the establishment and be different. I love Moulin Rouge for its music, its sights, and for its freshness. Very good.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-06-07</date>
		<username>DbNatura</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Spectacular Spectacular</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think that the "El Tango de Roxanne" scene may be the finest ever filmed. Period! Ewan McGregor shows such a breadth and depth in this movie. His other work has showcased his range, but never has one picture shown all of it. Nicole Kidman was a revelation. I'd never thought of her much one way or the other before this movie, but she was wonderful. The supporting cast were all brilliant.If there aren't at least Academy Award nominations for the 6 or 7 main characters, Baz Luhrman, set design, costumes and best song; then there is no justice in the world.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-07</date>
		<username>aiken (brooks@frnk.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Daring, and mostly successful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moulin Rouge is a refreshing break from today's world of test-marketed, demographically targeted, homogonized hollywood garbage. Loosely based around the myth of Oprheus, it's obviously the realization of Baz's dream rather than the result of committees and rewrites based on test screening report cards.The first half of the movie is dazzling and inventive, shockingly fun and surprisingly light on its feet. The movie slows a bit in the second half and gets more serious, but for me it still pulled it off quite nicely. Sure, it doesn't succeed all the time, and I would have edited it down about 10 minutes (mostly in the rehersal for the show-within-the-show), but so what? This is not a *perfect* film, this is a *very, very good* film.I completely understand why some people don't like Moulin Rouge. The movie takes a lot of chances, and isn't afraid to do completely unconventional (even absurd) things. This is not a "safe" movie in any sense of the word. To enjoy it, you really have to just let Baz take you through his vision; if you expect it to cater to your preconceptions of what a movie or musical should be like, you're going to be disappointed.However, if you've got any imagination at all, and you want to see something truly different -- go see this film right now. It really is something special.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-07</date>
		<username>Corro</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Totally moving. A fabulous blend of music, song, cast, and story.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I consider myself enough of a fan of mainstream cinema to know what makes a good movie.This is it.Baz Luhrmann and the cast and crew have combined to provide the ultimate musical presentation - you feel like you are actually watching a stage show as part of a theatre audience. The story and its telling are superb (if not new). From the first appearance of the curtain you become gripped by the emotions of the characters AND your own recollections of the various songs included in the magnificent soundtrack.I felt a wave of blissful goosebumps at several points as I was so moved by the performances of Nicole and Ewan (and Jacek Koman as well).Moulin Rouge is a reminder of the power of cinema.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-07</date>
		<username>tncook</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Beautiful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie was beautiful. The whole light/dark and use of colors was awesome. I love Lurhmann's work (ie Romeo and Juilet). The acting was nothing special, but then its hard to develop a character that we are used to when they randomly break out into a song.The story was mostly predictable, but it fit the "storybook musical" feel. You pretty much know what is going to happen, but the fun part was actually seeing it happen. Its a feast for the eyes. The music on the other hand was weird. The modern score was cool at times, but sometimes it seemed out of place, and way too stupid (like when he keeps saying "love lift us up where we belong, all we need is love". But there is something funny about a grizzled deep throated Argentinean singing Roxanne. I think that a few of the songs were original, the one that he sings when he meets Satine, and the "secret love song to remind them of their love"The choreography was nothing short of fabulous, it was in the sense of a full blown musical. The costumes... They were period, but with that feel that you could almost wear some of it out on the street today. I think that this is a movie that will set some trends, especially for women. I think that we will see a lot of that stunning red lipstick. But also things like corsets and fishnets. Everything in Satine' s wardrobe is amazing. She never looks less then glamorous, even when all she is wearing is a sheet and there is just something about Nichole Kidman in merrywidow and thigh-highs.I liked the movie for the style that it was done in. Everyone i went with complained about how it was badly acted and the plot lacked (although the movie was a remake of a 1952 version http://us.imdb.com/Title?0044926). I think that this movie could be watched over and over just because it is so beautiful. There is always something that your eyes draw to. I'll buy the DVD.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>Jason Kurylo (stodmyk)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Director Baz Luhrmann is easily one of the most important filmmakers of our time</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Baz Luhrmann is a freakin' genius.The man behind the 1996 visual orgasm that was William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet has done it again. This time, he hasn't breathed a taste of modern life into the Bard, but rather an even deader art form: the cinematic musical.Yes, Woody Allen tried it a couple of years ago with Everyone Says I Love You. But while Allen's material hasn't felt fresh since well before he ever laid eyes on his step-daughter, Luhrmann has injected innumerable pop references into his ode to Paris circa 1899.A young writer named Christian (played by Ewan McGregor), new to gay Paree, falls for a courtesan named Satine (Nicole Kidman) upon his first visit to the outrageous club Moulin Rouge. Okay, so the metaphor in the movie can be a little obvious at times... The story from there is interesting, but incidental. As shot by Luhrmann, these two are so captivating a screen couple the remainder of the film could involve them singing about poor penmanship and it would be worth admission.McGregor is every bit the smoldering star he promised he'd turn out to be, and Kidman once and for all proves that she is perhaps the most photogenic woman on the face of the planet. Both turn in surprisingly good vocal performances, and have no trouble carrying this picture.Luhrmann smothers every scene in overwhelming colour; even his usage of sepiatones or black and white shots are dripping in style and hue. The supporting cast is breathtakingly talented. Kudos to the casting agents and/or executives who fanagled the likes of Jim Broadbent as the sweaty, greedy, worldly bossman; and whomever it was that foresaw Richard Roxburgh as the ferociously needy Duke of Worcester should be summarily knighted.Luhrmann's vision in creating Moulin Rouge is almost incomprehendible. Four parts music video, three parts Picasso and five parts chocolate mousse, this film should take a number of Oscars next year; the Academy may as well hand over the best musical score statue now, and be surprised -- be very surprised -- if Luhrmann isn't nominated to walk away with the best director prize.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>bjp-2</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>How Wonderful Life is now this film is in the world!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I loved almost every second of this movie, hopefully this film will reinvigorate the musical genre. It really is a fantastic experience. Watching the film reminds one why you first started to attend the movies. The acting although slightly over the top by some is perfectly suited to their roles. Nicole Kidman is very impressive in her role and seems to now be in complete control of her craft, delivering on the promise that she showed in "Eyes Wide Shut" and "To Die For". Ewan McGregor is also very fine, and they both deliver the goods admirably when it comes to the singing. The musical numbers are simply inspired with the Roxanne Tango, Ewan McGregor singing Your Song for the first time, and Like A Virgin being personal highlights. The film itself is very funny but you may find that the tone changes somewhat in the second half and you should prepare yourself for it, it definitely tugs the heartstrings a little bit. The early sequences are very dazzling and fast moving reminiscent of "Cabaret" whilst the I believe the plot I believe can be interpreted as being a modern day version of "the red shoes". The costumes and sets are very impressive and pleasing to the eye as is every other facet of the film. Director Luhrmann has shown great visual panache in the creation of this wondrous film and turned what was an audacious undertaking likely to be rubbish into the benchmark by which future musicals will be judged. Overall, this is the best film that I have seen this year and I would thoroughly recommend it to anyone who loves music, movies or life. 10/10</fullReview>
	</review>

I realize not everyone will like it but it should at least be given a chance...</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>Tari</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Still shaking off the spell...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film was enchanting, and that's the best word for it. You feel almost like you've been pulled into another world, leaving all your cynicism at the door. This movie takes all of your guilty pleasures, all the things you love to love all alone, and makes it okay to love them right in broad daylight with everyone watching. It is intoxicating in its beauty, surprising in its originality, and utterly dreamlike. Ewan McGregor, who's not such a shabby actor in previous works, outdoes himself time and again - the "bohemian ideals" he espouses (truth, beauty, freedom, and - above all things - love) are clearly shown in every expression, be it lovelorn, tormented, or wholly joyous. Nicole Kidman turns in a solid performance as well, sometimes hilarious - sometimes poignant. It is, however, Mr. McGregor's film."Moulin Rouge" captures the quintessential nature of life - that everything we think is bad can be good and that everything we think is good can be bad, and that everything - good or bad - is magical and wondrous and should never be discarded as unworthy. Greed, lust, purity, artistic ideals, betrayal, jealousy, sacrifice, salvation, truth, and love triumphant even in tragedy - it's all here, wrapped up in a package that takes your breath away and makes you laugh, cry, and sing (and yes, you'll already know some of the words). A masterpiece of cinematography, choreography, effects and wardrobe, this film will not change your life...it will remind you why you live.</fullReview>
	</review>

I give Moulin Rouge a 10!!!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>moviebuf-11</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Sadly, I had high hopes for this one</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had been anxiously awaiting the opening of Moulin Rouge ever since seeing a full-color spread of the movie months ago in Vanity Fair. I should probably preface this by saying that I'm a real fan of the great Hollywood musicals, so my expectations were really high. After seeing the movie, I can't decide if I was disappointed, insulted or just plain exhausted.The film's frantic pace left me feeling drained. With all the money spent on lavish sets and costumes, it would have been nice for Baz Luhrman to let us actually see and enjoy some of the images, instead of hurling us into the middle of the action and then pulling us out again at break-neck speed. It had a schizophrenic plot that teetered between goofiness (come on, a singing moon???) and tragedy. Is it a farce, or is the film taking itself seriously?I think I could have gotten past the use of modern songs in a turn-of-the-century setting if they hadn't been used in such a hokey way. For example, Toulouse-Latrec and his cronies kept showing up to chime in during certain songs, reminding me of the chimpmunks who sang "Blue Moon" in "Babe." And why were they climbing up the roof of Satine's ridiculous boudoir that was housed inside a giant elephant???I do have to give credit to Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor for putting in excellent performances and surprisingly good singing. But their presence was overshadowed by Luhrman's nightmarish eye candy. If he had gone for more substance and less razzle dazzle, he would have made a wonderful movie. Instead, I don't know what the heck it was, but I think one movie critic described it best -- "An assault on the senses."</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>patria</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Stunning, exciting, romantic, what can one say?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I floated home on a romantic cloud, singing Elton John's "This is my song" and have been humming it to myself ever since (wish I knew the words). I was stunned to discover that Nicole and Ewan were the actual singers of the songs. Just amazing. Ewan McGregor, pleasant those I've found him in the past, wasn't until now one of my favourite actors. After this film, I fell completely in love with his depiction of a man in love. He was so convincing and sincere - and gorgeous! Nicole of course is always gorgeous; just didn't realise she could sing too. A whole new career for both of them!Baz Luhrmann has done it again. "Strictly Ballroom" is one of the most romantic movies I've ever seen and he's hit the target once more with Moulin Rouge. I've recommended it everyone I know and even the male members of my family enjoyed the movie. In fact, I can't wait to see it again and I don't often pay twice to revisit a film at the cinema (too expensive). But this time, I'm dying to see the whole thing again (and probably again, and again - especially when it comes out on video!). Congratulations, Baz, Nicole, Ewan and the whole cast!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>James L Vnuk</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Most Unique Film of the Year</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just got back from seeing the well-talked about "Moulin Rouge" with this review in mind ever since I left the theatre, and I have no idea to start. There's just too much swirling in my head about this very classy piece.I suppose I can start by saying that Moulin Rouge is one of the most unique, innovative, and original movies in recent years.Directed by Baz Luhrman (William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet, Stricly Ballroom), and set in the end of the 19th Century Paris, Moulin Rouge is the story of young Christian (Ewan McGregor) a writer in his first experiences in the Bohemian Underworld of Paris, and the lovely Courtesan Satine (Nicole Kidman), a well-endowed showgirl of the infamous Moulin Rouge Club/Brothel, and their ill-fated love affair. However, the club manager (played by Jim Broadbent) signs over the deeds to Moulin Rouge and ownership of Miss Satine to the Duke of Worcester (Richard Roxbourgh) in exchange for his funding for the greatest show Moulin Rouge will ever produce, and thus begins the ever-twisting love story of this magnificent movie.The performances of Mr. McGregor and Ms. Nicole Kidman (who, I might add, has never looked more gorgeous then she does here) are to say the least their best yet. Their love is believable, it's real, through the way they portray the character's emotions. No fabrication here like you see in your average romantic film. Cheers also to the exceptional works of John Leguizamo and Jim BroadbentThis film is both a musical and a love story, and Moulin Rouge is like nothing I've ever seen in either regard. The music is very important in this movie. One of the first true musicals to come out just for the silver screen in many a year, it uses what is called Anachronistic Music, meaning songs that don't normally coincide with the setting of the movie nor would you ever hear that kind of music if you were actually there. You'll hear from the cast bits from and pieces of "I'll Always Love You", "Roxanne", "Smells Like Teen Spirit", and even a full rendition of "Like A Virgin", as well as the fresh Operetta pieces, R&amp;B, and Pop Singles made especially for the movie. The anachronistic music is used remarkably well, and it's one of the most innovative scores I've ever heard.The one thing that grabbed me over everything else is the cinematography and the setting design. Baz has quite a bit of fun with the camera with this one. There's a lot of coreography in the movie, and the camera becomes a dancer itself. You wouldn't expect a musical/love story to be such a visual tour de force, and I didn't expect it either, and it made me dizzy from time to time. He uses some nifty tricks such as pulling individual frames from the film reel (so that the film purposely hops and skips) and speeding up or slowing down the speed of the film, using both techniques together with the pace of the music. Concerning the setting, Baz has taken a somewhat realistic setting and turning it into a virtual fantasy world. He uses CGI rather for an artistic effect rather then for eye-candy like most films tend to show, and the result is a specacular world filled with illustration and imagination. The costumes, make-up, and set designs are incredibly elaborate, dazzling, and almost overdone. Truly one of the most beautiful films to come out in a long time.I can almost guarantee that Moulin Rouge will make an appearance at this year's Golden Globe and Academy Awards. Here's what I think it will show in- Nominations in Cinematography, Musical Score, Art Direction-Set Decoration, Best Actor, Best Actress, and above all Costume Design.This is the first truly superb film of the summer, and quite possibly will be one of the best of the year. If you haven't already seen Moulin Rouge, do so as soon as you can. I wouldn't recommend it to a person with little appreciation for Avant Garde moviemaking, but I'd recommend it to everyone else.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>Scott Eichinger</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>GO!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>See it on the big screen. I loved it. Would see it again! Ewan and Nicole are both very good. Neither were meant to be singers, but they do a great job for being actors first. And they are both lovely to look at. I think the pop songs are going to make this a story that will be accessible to most anyone. It's over the top, but that makes it all the better. Kind of like Caberet, songs not furthering the plot, but mirroring the plot. And that Tango scene....I couldn't move my eyes away. It was so stunning to watch.Don't miss this one.Scott</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Still shaking off the spell...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film was enchanting, and that's the best word for it. You feel almost like you've been pulled into another world, leaving all your cynicism at the door. This movie takes all of your guilty pleasures, all the things you love to love all alone, and makes it okay to love them right in broad daylight with everyone watching. It is intoxicating in its beauty, surprising in its originality, and utterly dreamlike. Ewan McGregor, who's not such a shabby actor in previous works, outdoes himself time and again - the "bohemian ideals" he espouses (truth, beauty, freedom, and - above all things - love) are clearly shown in every expression, be it lovelorn, tormented, or wholly joyous. Nicole Kidman turns in a solid performance as well, sometimes hilarious - sometimes poignant. It is, however, Mr. McGregor's film."Moulin Rouge" captures the quintessential nature of life - that everything we think is bad can be good and that everything we think is good can be bad, and that everything - good or bad - is magical and wondrous and should never be discarded as unworthy. Greed, lust, purity, artistic ideals, betrayal, jealousy, sacrifice, salvation, truth, and love triumphant even in tragedy - it's all here, wrapped up in a package that takes your breath away and makes you laugh, cry, and sing (and yes, you'll already know some of the words). A masterpiece of cinematography, choreography, effects and wardrobe, this film will not change your life...it will remind you why you live.</fullReview>
	</review>

But little to any of them know, is that Satine is slowly dieing.I've been waiting for years for a good musical to come along, and it looks as if i finally got my wish. 		<username>(sp_pixie@lycos.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Art at its absolute finest</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moulin Rouge, despite its somewhat ecstatic beginning, is a genuine vision of the Bohemian ideals so often revered in the film: Truth, Beauty, Love, and Freedom. The film flows with such shocking beauty heart-wrenching honesty that it is difficult to remember yourself throughout the course of the story. A delightfully eccentric orgy of images and sounds, Moulin Rouge makes one cry from every pore in their body, makes them long for love and reality, despite its surreal and imaginative basis. The movie sets its own standards and guidelines. Baz Lurhmann is truly brilliant, and his creativity truly shines through this shimmering jewel of art and passion.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-05</date>
		<username>jedi_path (jedi_path@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A breathtaking masterpiece</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There aren't really any words I could use to describe the experience of seeing Moulin Rouge for the first time, but I will try.Baz Luhrmann is known films that distance the audience from reality by use of dance (Strictly Ballroom), language (Romeo + Juliet), and music here in Moulin Rouge. Yet in all of his films, the music conveys the meaning and the depth of emotion of the scene far better than just dialogue alone.Some people have criticized Moulin Rouge for its use of non-period songs, but in my opinion, the music is what brings the emotional story of Satine and Christian to life. Luhrmann draws upon songs familiar to us--ones likely to tug at our personal heart strings and call up memories of our reactions to the songs--and interweaves them spectacularly to amplify the feelings going on at the time. I couldn't imagine any sort of music that could define the particular feel of the Moulin Rogue club scene better than the mix of "Lady Marmalade," "Teen Spirit" and the "Can Can." It gives a sense of the spectacular, the thrill, the eroticism, and the bigger-than-life sensation, to which defies description. The Roxanne tango sequence was exceptional, using both the dramatic situations of the characters and the expertly woven dance sequence together, and using the music to build it into one the most brilliant sequences of cinema I've seen in a long time.The images of the film are as breathtaking as the musical scope. The first half rushes by in an absinthe-induced dream, where the people and situations seem bigger and brighter, and the hallucinations are just as real as the people. The style of the drab outer Parisian world seems to be cut from the same cloth as the early films and the degaurre-type photography, giving the sense of the old and the classic, but also the sense that the outer, older, non-bohemian world is somehow out-dated to the colorful, larger-than-life underworld of the Moulin Rouge. And then, just as the theatre of the period was beginning to, the style swings from spectacle to more realistic. Yet even these more down-to-earth scenes have visually exceptional and other-worldly quality. As for the acting, I think that as a whole, the ensemble cast did a fabulous job, getting back to the styles of acting at the time, when pratfalls and circus-like conditions were the norm.As to the plot, I've heard many people call it "fluff," so to speak. The plotline may be simplified, but the story--true love--is something that every human being longs for deep inside. True love, in its most basic form, doesn't need fancy trappings or complicated situations, just as most of the emotions racing around inside our hearts. It's simple, pure, and uncomplicated. And this simple love story, conveyed through a brilliant score and heart-felt acting, has carried away so many people with its scope. That scope doesn't necessarily come from wrinkles in the plotline, but from the scope of the human heart and our capacity to believe in true love.I think that Baz Luhrmann and his team have creating a trancendant piece of literature that has touched many people already, and will most likely be rewarded come Oscar time, whether or not the rest of entertainment year picks up steam.In closing, I would urge you to see it, and appreciate it for whatever it means to you.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-06-05</date>
		<username>jmuska</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>What a voice!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to see this movie without knowing really what to expect. I was a fan of Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor from the movies that they had done previously, but I was not prepared for the quality of their voices. Kidman has a beautiful voice and she is excellent as Satine in Moulin Rouge. However, McGregor has one of the most incredible voices I have ever heard. When he sang Elton John's "Your Song" to Kidman it moved me to tears and I am not easily moved to tears. Judge for yourself. I would not be surprised if McGregor's voice coupled with the rest of his performance leads to an Oscar nomination. At the very least I hope that this will not be the last time people get to hear this guy sing. That would be tragic.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-05</date>
		<username>Jen</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Luhrmann has done it again!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have to say I am a little biased-Luhrmann's Strictly Ballroom is my favorite movie. So I expected a lot from Moulin Rouge and thankfully was not disappointed. I can easily see how someone could be turned off by this movie. It really wasn't advertised as a kinetic, quickly-paced musical. So if you weren't expecting that, it would be a shock. And if you're looking for something like Pearl Harbor or Mummy Returns-DON'T SEE THIS MOVIE. To me though, this movie was spectacular! Ewan McGregor has long been a favorite and he displayed his tremendous talent once again as Christian. Who knew he had such a dreamy voice? I think I audibly sighed when he started singing Your Song. In the past I have not liked Nicole Kidman in the least, but she made me change my mind. She was beautiful and was able to pull off the role of Satine nicely. She was aloof one minute and charmingly in love the next. I was enthralled by this movie the minute it started and was completely engrossed until the end. I just can't wait to go see it again.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-05</date>
		<username>JARA-3</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Pudokin was right! Luhrman is too!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Editing is the only original and unique artform in film - Vladimir PudokinI read this quote recently on the Film 100 site and was struck by its truth. No film of recent memory drives this point home so well as Moulin Rouge. If no other talent from this movie is recognized next March, Jill Bilcock had better be. Baz Luhrman demands a breakneck pace for this movie, and Bilcock delivers.The story is simple: a rudimentary love triangle with all the usual outside pressures, including the villain holding the deed, a jealous co-worker, friends banding together to put on a show... the archetypes rattle on indefinitely.The acting is nearly nonexistent. Who has time to emote or construct a persona when the production is carried out a bullet-train speed? Casting then must carry the weight, and it does. Everyone from the leads on down to Warner, the thug, instantly project a character recognizably and completely. However, special kudos must go out to Ewan McGregor and Jim Broadbent for being especially effective in their roles. (And Nicole Kidman should be in every movie made... but that's just my opinion)After all this, you'd be tempted to guess that I disliked the film. I most emphatically did not. I loved it. This is a carefully constructed movie that has nothing to do with fin de siecle Paris and everything to do with youth, beauty, truth, freedom, and love. For those looking for a docudrama (documusical?) recounting the tawdry facts of life in Montmartre at the Moulin Rouge, I advise they hunt up John Huston, Jose Ferrer and their Moulin Rouge. For anyone who wants to understand the ecstacies of forbidden doomed love, of the joys of instant friendships that last a lifetime, however brief those lifetimes, for anyone who needs to learn about the rash painful but unregrettable follies of youth, send them to Satine, Christian, and Baz Luhrman's Moulin Rouge.So much remains to be said, yet I am too overwhelmed to say it all. The witty animations. The spectacular sets and models that serve the storytelling so much better than the real Paris could ever have. A film that does not pretend to be real, but knows it is a tale told for the entertainment and edification of the audience.Oh there are real flaws. Le Chocalate arrives at his big moment without adequate build up. And there is no reason that Leguizamo's character has to be Toulouse-Lautrec. The painter could have been alluded to in a crowd scene and more than fulfilled our historically minded friends. As for me, I'm looking to become a narcoleptic ArgentinianCan a play show us the very truth and nature of love? If Romeo and Juliet manages to, as Shakespeare in Love maintains, so to0 does Moulin Rouge.</fullReview>
	</review>
