	<review>
		<date>2005-03-07</date>
		<username>Jackson Booth-Millard</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Moulin Rouge</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have seen many emotional love stories, I have seen many heart warming musicals, and when the two are combined, you have a magnificent film, from BAFTA and Golden Globe nominated director Baz Luhrmann (Romeo + Juliet). It is 1899 in Paris, and aspiring young poet Christian (Golden Globe nominated Ewan McGregor) ignores his father's wishes, and joins the colourful, slightly dark underworld of the legendary Moulin Rouge club, run by Harold Zidler (BAFTA winning Jim Broadbent). While he is there, he not only has passion to create new art for the rich audiences of men, along with his friends and co-creators including Toulouse-Lautrec (John Leguizamo), but he starts a passionate affair with the highest paid star and most famous courtesan, Satine (Golden Globe winning, and Oscar nominated Nicole Kidman). Their romance is carried out in the club, but what makes their love a tragedy is the nasty Duke (Richard Roxburgh) saying he will only pay for the show, Spectacular Spectacular if Satine is his, love is forbidden in the Underworld, and more tragic, she is slowly dying of her illness (internal bleeding). The ending is not only a fantastic musical with passionate singing from McGregor and Kidman (well, all their singing is magnificent), but it has the tear-jerking ending with Satine dying in Christian's arms, and he finishes his story about this (he was writing about it). Also starring Garry McDonald as The Doctor, Jacek Koman as The Narcoleptic Argentinean, Matthew Whittet as Satie, The Lord of the Rings' David Wenham as Audrey and Kylie Minogue as The Green Fairy with the voice of Ozzy Osbourne. I think the film is also clever for the period story and characters singing modern love and pop culture songs in int, e.g. "I Will Always Love You", "Love Lifts Us Up", "Diamonds Are A Girl's Best Friend", "Lady Marmalade" (which Christina Aguilera, Pink, Lil Kim, Mya and Missy Elliot adapted fantastically) and of course, the great couple song, the Golden Globe nominated "Come What May", which was number 85 on 100 Years, 100 Songs. It won the Oscars for Best Art Direction-Set Decoration and Best Costume Design, and it was nominated for Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Makeup, Best Sound and Best Picture, it won the BAFTAs for the Anthony Asquith Award for Film Music for Craig Armstrong and Marius De Vries and Best Sound, and it was nominated for Best Special Visual Effects, Best Cinematography, Best Costume Design, Best Editing, Best Make Up/Hair, Best Production Design, Best Original Screenplay, the David Lean Award for Direction and Best Film, and it won the Golden Globes for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy and Best Original Score. Nicole Kidman was 21, and Ewan McGregor number 9 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars, McGregor was also number 2 on The 50 Greatest British Actors, the film was number 25 on 100 Years of Musicals, and it was number 10 on The 100 Greatest Musicals. Very good!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-04-22</date>
		<username>Theo Robertson</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>I Hate Musicals</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>With the exception of PINK FLOYD`S THE WALL I`ve always hated musicals . It`s the whole camp concept of men and women talking sensibly one moment and springing about like muppets on acid the next . Got your eye on a babe you fancy like mad lads ? Then sing to her and do a little hot shoe shuffle next time you see her boys , she will never forget you in much the same way she`ll never forget being mugged , or finding her previous lover in bed with her best friend You can see the point I`m making can`t you ? Musicals are silly and unrealistic and MOULIN ROUGE is no exception so I don`t really have to say why I disliked this film because it found it more silly and unrealistic than most musicals I`ve seen . I do recognise that there is a fair amount of cheek and temerity involved of having late 20th century pop songs in a film set in Paris in 1900 along with other post modernist anachronisms , and there is much technical worth in the areas of editing , cinematography and costume design , but I found MOULIN ROUGE to be a cheesy mess and turned off after 40 minutes</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>bob the moo</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually stunning and inventive, cool soundtrack and great love story ? but John Leguizamo's cartoon antics must go...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>English writer Christain finds himself introduced to the heady pleasures of the Moulin Rouge burlesque and to the fabulous beauty of the tragic Satine. Christian finds himself in a case of mistaken identify when Satine seduces him instead of the Duke (the potential backer for Satine's chance to star in a play). Before the mistake is realised Christian is in love and must struggle with envy while Satine plays along with the Duke in return for his money. But will love win out?Maybe I suffered from the hype but I was a tad disappointed in this film. At the heart it has a beautiful love story between Satine and Christian which has added spice due to her commitment to the Duke and her potential death from consumption. This side of the story plays well but the rest of it is almost like a cartoon. The cartoon/comedy side is fun too but it takes away from the love story.The director is great ? he did it with Romeo &amp; Juliet and he does it here. He has such an imagination and the film is a real joy to watch ? so clever, so inventive. But he has also allowed characters in that create a cartoon feel ? Toulouse-Lautrec and his fellow actors are prime examples. I found that this took away from my enjoyment slightly as it pushed some scenes from being imaginative and different into being silly.That said I still enjoyed the film. The central story is fantastic and visually it is amazing. The music is superb as well ? going from one style to the next, with absurd scenes to beautiful scenes (`Your Song' is my favourite scene, I could watch it 100 times!). Occasionally it doesn't work but it is audacious in the attempt.The cast are mostly great. Kidman and McGregor are both on top form and aquit themselves well ? both in the singing and the acting stakes. Jim Broadbent is good value as Harold, the club owner and Roxburgh gives a wonderfully smarmy performance as the Duke. John Leguizamo was good in Romeo &amp; Juliet, and Lurman should have left it there ? nobody can get two good performances out of this guy. His cartoon antics don't seem out of place in the first half of the film ? but when the mood changes he is left mugging and being irritating. He has some good moments ? but I really think that the guy needs to only do serious roles until he loses that irritating habit of mugging.Overall I thought this was a brave, inventive film that has a wonderful story at it's heart. However it is maybe hyped too much and I found that the cartoon antics of some of the characters were irritating rather than involving. But I still really enjoyed it!</fullReview>
	</review>
</movie>
